{{Update|date=January 2016}} {{Scandals in Turkey}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2014}} The '''2013 corruption scandal in [[Turkey]]''' refers to a criminal investigation that involves several key people in the [[Cabinet Erdoğan III|Turkish government]]. All of the 52 people detained on 17 December were connected in various ways with the ruling [[Justice and Development Party (Turkey)|Justice and Development Party]] (AKP). Prosecutors accused 14 people{{snd}} including [[Suleyman Aslan]], the director of state-owned [[Halkbank]], [[Iran]]ian businessman [[Reza Zarrab]], and several family members of cabinet ministers{{snd}} of [[bribery]], [[corruption]], [[fraud]], [[money laundering]] and [[gold]] [[smuggling]].<ref name="Turkey's Mother of All Corruption Scandals">[https://foreignpolicy.com/2015/01/06/why-turkeys-mother-of-all-corruption-scandals-refuses-to-go-away/ Why Turkey’s Mother of All Corruption Scandals Refuses to Go Away] - ForeignPolicy.com </ref>
At the heart of the scandal was an alleged "gas for gold" scheme with [[Iran]] involving Aslan, who had US$4.5 million in cash stored in shoeboxes in his home, and Zarrab, who was involved in about US$9.6 billion of gold trading in 2012. Both men were arrested.<ref name="businessinsider1">{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/recap-of-corruption-scandal-in-turkey-2013-12 |title=Recap Of Corruption Scandal In Turkey |publisher=Business Insider |date= |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref> The scheme worked after officials of the Turkish government found a loophole in U.S. sanctions against Iran that allowed them to get Iranian oil and gas. The Turks exported some US$13 billion of gold to Iran directly, or through the [[UAE]], between March 2012 and July 2013. In return, the Turks received Iranian natural gas and oil. The transaction was carried out through Turkish state-owned bank, Halkbank. In January 2013, the [[Obama administration]] decided to close this loophole but instead of immediately charging Halkbank, the U.S. government allowed its gold trading activities to continue until July 2013, because Turkey was an important U.S. ally regarding U.S. policy in the [[Syrian Civil War]], and the U.S. had been working on a [[Iran nuclear deal framework|nuclear deal with Iran]].<ref name="businessinsider1"/>
Then-Prime Minister Erdoğan (now [[President of Turkey]]) was out on a foreign tour of Pakistan when the scandal broke, which analysts believe changed the response of the AKP or influenced those with the tapes to leak them at a time when Erdoğan was touring a key ally ([[Pakistan]]) abroad.<ref name=fireworks>{{cite news |author=Özgür Altuncu |title=Başbakan Erdoğan Pakistan'da havai fişeklerle karşılandı |language=tr |trans-title=Prime Minister Erdoğan was greeted in Pakistan with fireworks |newspaper=[[Hürriyet Daily News]] |url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/dunya/25423583.asp |date=23 December 2013 |accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref>
==Police investigation and allegations== On 17 December 2013, the Financial Crime Unit of the Istanbul Security Directorate detained 47 people, including officials from TOKİ (Housing Development Administration of Turkey), the [[Ministry of Environment and Urban Planning (Turkey)|Ministry of Environment and Urban Planning]], and the [[Fatih|District Municipality of Fatih]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://sozcu.com.tr/2013/genel/buyuk-rusvet-ve-yolsuzluk-operasyonunda-gozaltina-alinanlarin-isimleri-425968/ |title=Büyük rüşvet operasyonunda gözaltına alınanların işlemleri sürüyor |language=tr |trans-title=Great bribery operation continues operations in detainees |newspaper=[[Sözcü]] |date=18 December 2013 |accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref> [[Barış Güler]], [[Kaan Çağlayan]] and [[Oğuz Bayraktar]], who are sons of the Turkish ministers, [[Muammer Güler]] ([[Ministry of the Interior (Turkey)|Minister of the Interior]]), [[Zafer Çağlayan]] (Minister of Economy), and [[Erdoğan Bayraktar]] ([[Ministry of Environment and City Planning (Turkey)|Minister of Environment and Urban Planning]]) were implicated, as well as Mustafa Demir, the mayor of the district municipality of Fatih; the real estate businessman [[Ali Ağaoğlu]]; Süleyman Aslan, the general manager of [[Halk Bankası|Halkbank]] and the [[Iran]]ian businessman [[Reza Zarrab]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/ekonomi/25378685.asp |title=İstanbul'da yolsuzluk ve rüşvet operasyonu |language=tr |trans-title=Corruption and bribery operation in Istanbul |newspaper=[[Hürriyet Daily News]] |date=17 December 2013 |accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref> who was considered as the key suspect in the investigation, who was reportedly involved in a money laundering scheme particularly regarding his transfer of gold and money to Iran via Turkey’s government-controlled Halkbank as part of a strategy to bypass United States-led sanctions on Iran.<ref name="Turkey's Mother of All Corruption Scandals"/> Demir was detained on accusations of approving the construction license for a hotel near the route of the recently inaugurated [[Marmaray]] railway, despite warnings from Japanese engineers that the construction could put the tunnel at risk of collapsing. Demir was investigated for ordering the ministry report to be shelved in exchange for bribes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/turkish-pm-erdogan-says-those-who-target-him-through-graft-probe-will-not-succeed.aspx?pageID=238&nID=60154&NewsCatID=338|title=Turkish PM Erdoğan says those who target him through graft probe will not succeed - POLITICS|publisher=}}</ref>
Moreover, [[Egemen Bağış]], the Minister of European Union Affairs, is cited in newspaper articles as a potential suspect of bribery related to [[Reza Zarrab]] who has business affiliations with [[Babak Zanjani]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.radikal.com.tr/turkiye/uc_bakana_rusvet_suclamasi-1166735 | title=Üç bakana rüşvet suçlaması | language=tr | trans-title=Three facing charges of bribery | date=18 December 2013 | newspaper=[[Radikal]] | accessdate=18 December 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131219021159/http://www.radikal.com.tr/turkiye/uc_bakana_rusvet_suclamasi-1166735 | archive-date=19 December 2013 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://t24.com.tr/haber/yolsuzluk-ve-rusvet-sorusturmasinda-egemen-bagis-goruntuleri-de-cikti/246398 | title=Yolsuzluk ve rüşvet soruşturmasında Egemen Bağış görüntüleri de çıktı! |language=tr |trans-title=Corruption and bribery investigation Egemen Bagis also output images! | date=19 December 2013 | publisher=T24 | accessdate=19 December 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=Thomas Erdbrink | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/05/world/middleeast/to-this-tycoon-iran-sanctions-are-like-gold.html?_r=0| title=To This Tycoon, Iran Sanctions Were Like Gold| date=5 October 2013 | newspaper=[[The New York Times]] | accessdate=5 October 2013}}</ref> As part of corruption claims along with 3 other ministers, Bağış was the only one out of the four charged ministers who had not resigned on 25 December 2013. Prime Minister Erdoğan announced a major cabinet reshuffle, removing Bağış from his post as the Minister for European Union through his publicly unannounced official resignation.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.resmigazete.gov.tr/main.aspx?home=http://www.resmigazete.gov.tr/eskiler/2013/12/20131227.htm&main=http://www.resmigazete.gov.tr/eskiler/2013/12/20131227.htm |title=BAKANLARIN İSTİFASI VE ATANMASINA DAİR İŞLEM |date=25 December 2013 |agency=T.C. Resmi Gazete |accessdate=26 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131222025026/http://www.resmigazete.gov.tr/main.aspx?home=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.resmigazete.gov.tr%2Feskiler%2F2013%2F12%2F20131227.htm&main=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.resmigazete.gov.tr%2Feskiler%2F2013%2F12%2F20131227.htm |archivedate=22 December 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref>
The police confiscated some US$17.5 million as money used in bribery during the investigation; US$4.5 million was found at Süleyman Aslan's residence and US$750,000 at Barış Güler's.<ref>{{cite news |date=20 December 2013 |url=http://www.aktifhaber.com/operasyonda-ele-gecirilen-para-miktari-905081h.htm |title=Operasyonda Ele Geçirilen Para Miktari |language=tr |trans-title=The amount of money seized in operation |publisher=Aktif Haber |accessdate=7 November 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150606215900/http://www.aktifhaber.com/operasyonda-ele-gecirilen-para-miktari-905081h.htm |archive-date=6 June 2015 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Prosecutors accused 14 people including Barış Güler, Kaan Çağlayan, Süleyman Aslan and Reza Zarrab of bribery, corruption, fraud, [[money laundering]] and [[smuggling]] gold. On 21 December, the court ordered the arrest of these 14 people.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/25412674.asp |date=21 December 2013 |title=2 Bakan oğlu ile Reza Zarrab tutuklandı |language=tr |trans-title=Reza was arrested with two Ministers son Zarraba |newspaper=[[Hürriyet Daily News]] |accessdate=7 November 2014 }}</ref>
In total, 91 people were detained in the investigation; 26 of them were arrested by the court.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cumhuriyet.com.tr/haber/21119/Operasyonda_toplam_tutuklu_sayisi_ve_isimler.html |title=Operasyonda toplam tutuklu sayısı ve isimler |language=tr |trans-title=The total number of prisoners and the operation names |date=21 December 2013 |newspaper=[[Cumhuriyet]] |accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref>
===Second wave=== Several newspapers reported that a new investigation was expected on 26 December, possibly involving then-Prime Minister (now [[President of Turkey]]) Erdoğan's sons, [[Bilal Erdoğan]] and [[Ahmet Burak Erdoğan|Burak]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://haber.sol.org.tr/devlet-ve-siyaset/erdogan-oglunu-koruyor-sorusturma-savcidan-alindi-haberi-84919 |title=Erdoğan oğlunu koruyor: Soruşturma savcıdan alındı! |language=tr |trans-title=Erdoğan remains sons were taken from prosecutors investigating! |date=26 December 2013 |newspaper=[[SoL (newspaper)|SoL]] |accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref> as well as certain [[Al-Qaeda]] affiliates from [[Saudi Arabia]] such as Sheikh Yaseen Al Qadi and Osama Khoutub.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.todayszaman.com/news-335038-report-al-qaeda-suspects-flee-after-turkish-govt-blocks-raid.html |title=Report: Al Qaeda suspects flee after Turkish gov't blocks raid |newspaper=[[Today's Zaman]] |date=26 December 2013 |accessdate=7 November 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141108013004/http://www.todayszaman.com/news-335038-report-al-qaeda-suspects-flee-after-turkish-govt-blocks-raid.html |archive-date=8 November 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The police officers in Istanbul Security Directorate, newly appointed by the government just a few days previously, refused to carry out their orders, and the Deputy Director of Public Prosecutions did not approve this new operation. The man behind this second investigation, Prosecutor [[Muammer Akkaş]], was dismissed on the same day.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://haber.gazetevatan.com/2-dalga-emniyete-takildi/595535/1/gundem |title=Savcı operasyondan alındı |language=tr |trans-title='Received from the Attorney-operation' |newspaper=[[Vatan]] |date=26 December 2013 |accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref> Akkaş said he was prevented from performing his duty.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.todayszaman.com/news-335036-prosecutor-removed-from-new-graft-probe-amid-concerns-of-cover-up.html |title=Prosecutor removed from new graft probe amid concerns of cover-up |newspaper=[[Today's Zaman]] |date=26 December 2013 |accessdate=7 November 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141108012858/http://www.todayszaman.com/news-335036-prosecutor-removed-from-new-graft-probe-amid-concerns-of-cover-up.html |archive-date=8 November 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
A second wave of arrests was planned, and a list was [[News leak|leaked]] to the press.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://haber.sol.org.tr/devlet-ve-siyaset/iste-ikinci-dalgadaki-gozalti-listesi-haberi-84969 |title=İşte ikinci dalgadaki gözaltı listesi! |language=tr |trans-title=Here is the list of detainees in the second wave! |newspaper=[[SoL (newspaper)|SoL]] |date=27 December 2013 |accessdate=7 November 2014 }}</ref>
At midnight on 7 January, a government decree was published removing 350 police officers from their positions, including the chiefs of the units dealing with financial crimes, smuggling and organised crime.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-25637710 |title=Turkish corruption probe row deepens |publisher=BBC News |date=7 January 2014 |accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref> [[Fethullah Gülen]] described the decree as a purge of civil servants, while then-[[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan|Prime Minister Erdoğan]] (now [[President of Turkey]]) described the corruption investigation as a "judicial coup" by those jealous of his success, backed by foriengers, namely a "dirty plot" of the [[Gülen movement]].<ref>{{cite news|agency=Reuters |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jan/07/turkish-police-removed-posts-corruption |title=Hundreds of Turkish police removed from posts |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=7 January 2014 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140110144248/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jan/07/turkish-police-removed-posts-corruption |archivedate=10 January 2014 }} </ref>
==Government reaction== Since the beginning of the investigation, the [[Justice and Development Party (Turkey)|Justice and Development Party (AKP)]] government has started a purge in the police force; sacking dozens of police chiefs, most notably [[Hüseyin Çapkın]], the Chief of Police in Istanbul.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.radikal.com.tr/turkiye/istanbul_emniyetinde_25_mudurun_yeri_degisti-1167417|title=İstanbul Emniyeti'nde 25 müdürün yeri değişti|language=tr |trans-title=Positions of the 25 police managers has changed in ıstanbul|newspaper=[[Radikal]] |date=22 December 2013|accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref> The Ministry of the Interior and the [[Ministry of Justice (Turkey)|Ministry of Justice]] also changed their regulations, forcing security forces to inform their seniors of their actions at all times.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/25412900.asp |title=Adli Kolluk Yönetmeliği'nde değişiklik yapıldı |language=tr |trans-title=Changes were made to the Judicial Police Regulation |newspaper=[[Hürriyet Daily News]] |date=21 December 2013 |accessdate=7 November 2014 }}</ref> This received criticism from the [[Turkish Bars Association|Union of Turkish Bar Associations]], who are taking the case to the [[Turkish Council of State]].<ref>{{cite news |author=Zeynep Gürcanli |url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/25426050.asp |title=Adli Kolluk Yönetmeliği'ne iptal davası |language=tr |trans-title=Regulation of Judicial Police action for annulment |newspaper=[[Hürriyet Daily News]] |date=23 December 2013 |accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref> The [[Turkish Council of State]] overturned the change of these regulations on 27 December, much to the disappointment of Prime Minister Erdoğan.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/25453285.asp |title=Danıştay Adli Kolluk Yönetmeliği'ni durdurdu |language=tr |trans-title=Judicial Police stopped by the State Council Regulations |newspaper=[[Hürriyet Daily News]] |date=28 December 2013 |accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref>
Various opposition sources accused the government of trying to influence the judiciary system and covering up the corruption. Among them was the [[Nationalist Movement Party]] MP [[Oktay Vural]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.zaman.com.tr/gundem_mhpli-vural-hukumet-operasyonun-ustunu-ortup-delilleri-karartmaya-calisiyor_2185211.html |title=MHP'li Vural: Hükümet, operasyonun üstünü örtüp delilleri karartmaya çalışıyor |language=tr |trans-title=MHP Vural: The government is trying to evidence the top of the wrap operation blackout |agency=[[Xinhua News Agency]] |newspaper=[[Zaman (newspaper)|Zaman]] |date=18 December 2013 |accessdate=7 November 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141108013733/http://www.zaman.com.tr/gundem_mhpli-vural-hukumet-operasyonun-ustunu-ortup-delilleri-karartmaya-calisiyor_2185211.html |archive-date=8 November 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> A heated controversy erupted after the release on [[YouTube]] of audio recordings in which Erdoğan was reportedly heard telling his son, Bilal, to urgently get rid of tens of millions of dollars. Erdoğan has claimed the recordings were a montage but the experts begged to differ.<ref name="Turkey's Mother of All Corruption Scandals"/>
In late December, ''[[Hurriyet]]'' and ''[[Yeni Safak]]'' papers published comments by Erdoğan stating he believes he is the ultimate target of a corruption and bribery probe of his allies. The Turkish Prime Minister told journalists that anyone attempting to enmesh him in the scandal would be "left empty handed." Erdoğan reshuffled his Cabinet on 25 Dec, replacing 10 ministers hours after three ministers, whose sons were detained in relation to the probe, resigned. One of those ministers called on Erdoğan to also step down. The ministers’ sons were questioned over the scandal focusing on alleged illicit money transfers to Iran and bribery for construction projects. Two of them were later arrested on bribery charges.<ref name="intimated.com">{{cite news|agency=Associated Press |title=Turkish PM Says He Is Target of Graft Probe |url=http://intimated.com/turkish-pm-says-he-is-target-of-graft-probe/ |publisher=Intimated |date=26 December 2013 |accessdate=26 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131227111258/http://intimated.com/turkish-pm-says-he-is-target-of-graft-probe/ |archivedate=27 December 2013 }}</ref>
According to [[Hüseyin Çelik]], who is serving as government spokesman, the four ministers who are involved in the investigation offered their resignation to the Prime Minister [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan|Erdoğan]] on 22 December.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.aksam.com.tr/siyaset/huseyin-celik-4-bakan-istifasini-sundu-sahidim/haber-270751 |title=Hüseyin Çelik: 4 Bakan istifasını sundu, şahidim |language=tr |trans-title=Hüseyin Celik: 4 offered the resignation of Ministers, I swear |newspaper=[[Akşam]] |date=21 December 2013 |accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref>
Erdoğan blamed the investigation on an international [[List of political conspiracies|conspiracy]] and vowed revenge on the [[Gülen movement|Islamic community]] of the preacher [[Fethullah Gülen]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dokuzeylulgazetesi.com/haber/basbakan_ininize_girecegiz_didik_didik_edecegiz-4496.html |title=Başbakan: İninize Gireceğiz Didik Didik Edeceğiz |language=tr |trans-title=Prime Minister: We'll enter your Lair We Will Die |publisher=Dokuzeylulgazetesi.com |date=22 December 2013 |accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref> There had been an antagonism between Erdoğan and Gülen for some time: [[Hakan Şükür]], who is often regarded as a disciple of Gülen, had resigned his post in Justice and Development Party on 16 December.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.trthaber.com/haber/gundem/hakan-sukur-istifa-etti-112463.html |title=Hakan Şükür istifa etti |language=tr |trans-title=Hakan Şükür resigns |date=16 December 2013 |publisher=TRT Haber |accessdate=7 November 2014 }}</ref> Government officials accused Gulen and his followers of treason and started referring to them as "terrorists."<ref name="Turkey's Mother of All Corruption Scandals"/>
Erdoğan defended [[Halkbank]] chief executive [[Süleyman Aslan]], describing him as "honest person". Aslan was charged with taking bribes by the prosecutors while the police are said to reportedly have found US$4.5 million in cash stored in shoe boxes in Aslan’s home.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/turkish-pm-erdogan-says-those-who-target-him-through-graft-probe-will-not-succeed.aspx?pageID=238&nID=60154&NewsCatID=338 |title=Turkish PM Erdoğan says those who target him through graft probe will not succeed |website=Hurriyetdailynews.com |date=2013-12-26 |accessdate=2016-07-17}}</ref> After Aslan was arrested the bank's stock went down 32% for the year.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/turkey-gas-for-gold-deal-with-iran-2013-12 |title=Turkey Gas For Gold Deal With Iran |publisher=Business Insider |date=2013-12-27 |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref> Erdoğan also threatened [[Francis J. Ricciardone, Jr.|Francis Ricciardone]], the [[United States Ambassador to Turkey|U.S. ambassador to Turkey]], with expulsion.<ref>{{cite news |author=Esra Kaya |url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/25418951.asp |title=Ülkemizde tutmayız |language=tr |trans-title=We do not keep our country |newspaper=[[Hürriyet Daily News]] |date=22 December 2013 |accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref>
Erdoğan left the country for an official visit to Pakistan on 23 December, while the scandal was dominating the headlines.<ref name=fireworks/>
Muhammed Mısır, a bureaucrat in the [[Ministry of Health (Turkey)|Ministry of Health]], resigned after bribery allegations on 24 December.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.bugun.com.tr/son-dakika/saglik-bakanliginda-istifa-haberi/908999 |title=Sağlık Bakanlığı'nda Muhammed Mısır istifa etti |language=tr |trans-title=Minister of Health Muhammed Mısır has resigned |publisher=Bugun.com.tr |date=24 December 2013 |accessdate=7 November 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141108013735/http://www.bugun.com.tr/son-dakika/saglik-bakanliginda-istifa-haberi/908999 |archive-date=8 November 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
[[Muammer Güler]] (Minister of the Interior) and [[Zafer Çağlayan]] (Minister of Economy), both of whose sons were arrested in the anti-corruption operation, resigned together on the morning of 25 December.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/25438044.asp |title=Bakan Çağlayan ile Güler istifa etti |language=tr |trans-title=Ministers Çağlayan and Güler resigned |newspaper=[[Hürriyet Daily News]] |date=25 December 2013 |accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref> That same afternoon, [[Erdoğan Bayraktar]] (Minister of Environment and Urban Planning) resigned both as minister and as a member of parliament. Bayraktar said that he did not take kindly to having been forced into resignation, and that Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdoğan should resign as well, claiming that he had done everything with the Prime Minister's approval.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/25440241.asp |title=Erdoğan Bayraktar istifa etti |language=tr |trans-title=Erdoğan Bayraktar has resigned |newspaper=[[Hürriyet Daily News]] |date=25 December 2013 |accessdate=7 November 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=Tim Arango |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/26/world/europe/turkish-cabinet-members-resign.html?pagewanted=1&_r=0&hp |title=Graft Scandal Is Approaching Turkey Premier |newspaper=The New York Times |page=A1 |date=26 December 2013 |accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref>
[[İdris Naim Şahin]], former Minister of the Interior, has resigned from Justice and Development Party on 25 December. He said the government's crackdown on the police organization and the judiciary system could not be explained with reason or the notions of law and justice.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/25442203.asp |title=İdris Naim Şahin istifa etti |language=tr |trans-title=İdris Naim Şahin resigns |newspaper=[[Hürriyet Daily News]] |date=25 December 2013 |accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref>
450 policemen in the Financial Crimes department were forbidden to enter the Istanbul Security Department HQ.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://emedya.cumhuriyet.com.tr/haber/22841/450_polisin_Vatan_Emniyet_e_girmesi_yasaklandi.html# |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131227092703/http://emedya.cumhuriyet.com.tr/haber/22841/450_polisin_Vatan_Emniyet_e_girmesi_yasaklandi.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-12-27 |title=450 polisin Vatan Emniyet'e girmesi yasaklandı |publisher=Emedya.cumhuriyet.com.tr }}</ref>
[[Erdal Kalkan]], a member of parliament in the constituency of [[Izmir]] from the ruling AKP, resigned from his party on 26 December because of the ongoing scandal.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/turkce/haberler/2013/12/131226_kalkan_istifa.shtml |title=AKP'de iki milletvekili istifa etti |language=tr |trans-title=Two AKP deputies resign |publisher=BBC News |date=27 December 2013 |accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref> Haluk Özdalga, Member of Parliament in the constituency of Ankara, resigned from AKP for the same reason.<ref>{{cite news |date=27 December 2013 |url=http://sozcu.com.tr/2013/gundem/haluk-ozdalga-istifa-etti-431505/ |title=AKP Ankara Milletvekili Haluk Özdalga da istifa etti |language=tr |trans-title=AKP Ankara deputy Haluk Özdalga resigned |newspaper=[[Sözcü]] |accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref> [[Ertuğrul Günay]], another MP in the constituency of Izmir and former Minister of Culture, was the third one to resign from AKP.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/25452913.asp |title=Ertuğrul Günay AKP'den istifa etti |language=tr |trans-title=Ertugrul Gunay resigned from the AKP |newspaper=[[Hürriyet Daily News]] |date=27 December 2013 |accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref> These three ex-members of AKP were each separately had been on investigation by AKP's internal discipline committee with the accusation of opposing AKP's own regulations. They all resigned before the committee reached a verdict.
On 31 December, [[Burdur Province|Burdur]] deputy [[Hasan Hami Yıldırım]] resigned from the AKP, reducing the number of AKP parliamentarians to 320. Yıldırım accused the government of obstructing the investigation into the scandal.<ref>{{cite news |author=Daniel Dombey |title=Turkey economy chief blames corruption probe for market fall |newspaper=[[Financial Times]] |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/fb7534e2-722a-11e3-bff7-00144feabdc0.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140102131727/http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/fb7534e2-722a-11e3-bff7-00144feabdc0.html |date=31 December 2013 |archive-date=2 January 2014}}</ref> He also criticized the campaign of “insults” and “defamation” against Islamic scholar [[Fethullah Gülen]] and his [[Hizmet movement]], which he considered an attempt to "eradicate a civil society movement.”<ref>{{cite news |title=Another AKP deputy, Hami Yıldırım, resigns in protest |agency=[[Cihan News Agency]] |url=https://www.cihan.com.tr/en/another-ak-party-deputy-hami-yildirim-resigns-in-protest-1243110.htm |date=31 December 2013 |accessdate=20 May 2016 }}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Erdoğan's government dismissed or reassigned thousands of police officers and hundreds of judges and prosecutors - including those leading the investigation - and passed a law increasing government control of the judiciary.<ref>{{cite web|last=Tattersall |first=Nick |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-turkey-corruption-idUSBREA410NE20140502 |title=Turkey dismisses corruption case that has dogged PM Erdoğan |publisher=Reuters |date=2014-05-02 |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref>
===Cabinet reshuffle=== In a speech to the press on the evening of 25 December, Prime Minister [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]] announced the reshuffle of 10 members of his [[Cabinet Erdoğan III|cabinet]]<ref name="intimated.com"/> in light of the scandal, saying that the reshuffle was to replace the three ministers who had resigned earlier in the day and others who were planning mayoral runs in the [[Turkish local elections, 2014|local elections in March 2014]]. This included the removal of Minister for European Union and Chief Negotiator [[Egemen Bağış]], another figure in the scandal, from office.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.resmigazete.gov.tr/main.aspx?home=http://www.resmigazete.gov.tr/eskiler/2013/12/20131227.htm&main=http://www.resmigazete.gov.tr/eskiler/2013/12/20131227.htm |title=BAKANLARIN İSTİFASI VE ATANMASINA DAİR İŞLEM |date=25 December 2013 |agency=T.C. Resmi Gazete |accessdate=26 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131222025026/http://www.resmigazete.gov.tr/main.aspx?home=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.resmigazete.gov.tr%2Feskiler%2F2013%2F12%2F20131227.htm&main=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.resmigazete.gov.tr%2Feskiler%2F2013%2F12%2F20131227.htm |archivedate=22 December 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | author1 = Orhan Coskun | author2 = Ece Toksabay | date = 25 December 2013 | title = Hit by scandal and resignations, Turk PM names new ministers | url = http://www.thestar.com.my/News/World/2013/12/26/Turkey-vows-no-coverup-despite-purge-of-graft-investigators.aspx | archive-url = https://archive.is/20131225224734/http://www.thestar.com.my/News/World/2013/12/26/Turkey-vows-no-coverup-despite-purge-of-graft-investigators.aspx | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 25 December 2013 | newspaper = The Star Online | accessdate = 25 December 2013}}</ref> The changes to the cabinet are:<ref>{{cite news | date = 26 December 2013 | title = Kabinede 10 bakan değişti | trans-title = 10 ministers in the Cabinet changed | url = http://www.zaman.com.tr/politika_kabinede-10-bakan-degisti_2189044.html | newspaper = Zaman Newspaper | accessdate = 26 January 2013 | language = tr | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20131227061235/http://www.zaman.com.tr/politika_kabinede-10-bakan-degisti_2189044.html | archive-date = 27 December 2013 | dead-url = yes | df = dmy-all }}</ref>
* [[Emrullah İşler]] – [[Deputy Prime Minister (Turkey)|Deputy Prime Minister]] – replacing [[Bekir Bozdağ]] (see below entry) * [[Bekir Bozdağ]] – [[Ministry of Justice (Turkey)|Minister of Justice]] – replacing [[Sadullah Ergin]] * [[Ayşenur İslam]] – [[Ministry of Family and Social Policy (Turkey)|Minister of Family and Social Policy]] – replacing [[Fatma Şahin]] * [[Nihat Zeybekci]] – [[Ministry of Economy (Turkey)|Minister of Economic Affairs]] – replacing [[Zafer Çağlayan]] (who resigned) * [[İdris Güllüce]] – [[Ministry of Environment and Urban Planning (Turkey)|Minister of Environment and Urban Planning]] – replacing [[Erdoğan Bayraktar]] (who resigned) * [[Akif Çağatay Kılıç]] – [[Ministry of Youth and Sports (Turkey)|Minister of Youth and Sports]] – replacing [[Suat Kılıç]] * [[Efkan Ala]] – [[Ministry of the Interior (Turkey)|Minister of the Interior]] – replacing [[Muammer Güler]] (who resigned) * [[Lütfi Elvan]] – [[Ministry of Transport and Communication (Turkey)|Minister of Transport and Communication]] – replacing [[Binali Yıldırım]] * [[Fikri Işık]] – [[Ministry of Science, Industry and Technology (Turkey)|Minister of Science, Industry and Technology]] – replacing [[Nihat Ergün]] * [[Mevlüt Çavuşoğlu]] – [[Ministry of European Union Affairs|Minister for European Union Affairs]] – replacing [[Egemen Bağış]]
==Other controversies== On 24 December, another video began to circulate that shows Ali Erdoğan, nephew and bodyguard of Prime Minister Erdoğan, instructing a police commissioner to abuse the detainees who had protested his uncle and hurling insults at him when he refuses.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ulusalkanal.com.tr/gundem/erdoganin-yegeni-karakol-basti-h19848.html |title=Erdoğan'ın yeğeni karakol bastı |language=tr |trans-title=Erdoğan's nephew station raided |publisher=Ulusal Kanal |date=24 December 2013 |accessdate=7 November 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141108013023/http://www.ulusalkanal.com.tr/gundem/erdoganin-yegeni-karakol-basti-h19848.html |archive-date=8 November 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
On 23 December, 35-year-old Hakan Yüksekdağ, a police commissioner in the Smuggling and Battle Against Organized Crimes Department of the [[Ankara Province]] Security Directory, was found dead in his car. His relatives dispute the official claim that Yüksekdağ committed suicide.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://haber.sol.org.tr/devlet-ve-siyaset/emniyet-mudurunun-yakinlari-intihar-olamaz-buyuk-bir-operasyon-haberi-84724 |title=Emniyet Müdürü'nün yakınları: İntihar olamaz, büyük bir operasyon |language=tr |trans-title=Relatives Chief of Police: Suicide not a big operation |publisher=Sol |date=23 December 2014 |accessdate=7 November 2014 }}</ref>
On 24 December, Abdi Altınok, an Assistant Chief of Police in the [[Isparta Province]] Security Directory, committed suicide.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ntvmsnbc.com/id/25487798 |title=Emniyet Müdür Yardımcısı intihar etti |language=tr |trans-title=Deputy Chief Constable commits suicide |publisher=Ntvmsnbc |date=24 December 2013 |accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref>
Billionaire [[Babak Zanjani]], an alleged partner and accomplice of Reza Zarrab, was arrested in [[Iran]] on 30 December.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-25551849 |title=Iranian billionaire Babak Zanjani 'arrested' |publisher=BBC News |date=30 December 2013 |accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref>
==See also== * [[2013–14 protests in Turkey]] * [[Corruption in Turkey]] * [[Ergenekon trials]] * [[Justice and Development Party (Turkey)|Justice and Development Party]] * [[McCarthyism]]<ref name="McCarthyism_in_Turkey">{{cite news |title='Görevden almak zorundayım' |language=tr |trans-title='I have to dismiss' |url=http://haber.gazetevatan.com/gorevden-almak-zorundayim/599071/1/gundem |publisher=[[Vatan]] |date=8 January 2014 |accessdate=8 January 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140114000025/http://haber.gazetevatan.com/gorevden-almak-zorundayim/599071/1/gundem |archive-date=14 January 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * [[Turkish local elections, 2014]] * [[U.S. v Zarrab]]

bill|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/nov/11/thailand-protests-amnesty-bill|accessdate=13 January 2014|newspaper=The Guardian|date=11 November 2013}} * Shinawatra family influence * Proposed journal|last1=Korotayev|first1=Andrey|last2=Issaev|first2=Leonid|last3=Zinkina|first3=Julia|title=Center-Periphery Dissonance as a Possible Factor of the Revolutionary Wave of 2013-2014: A Cross-National Analysis|journal=Cross-Cultural Research|date=2015|volume=49|issue=5|url=http://cliodynamics.ru/download/Cross-Cultural%20Research-2015-Korotayev-Dissonance_461-88.pdf|accessdate=29 May 2016}} * Royal succession{{cite news|title=Where is Thailand heading after protests|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-26467100|accessdate=23 May 2014|newspaper=BBC News|date=7 March 2014|quote=There is one other crucial element in this bitter conflict, the issue of the royal succession.}} | goals = * Removal of Thaksin-affiliated [[Pheu Thai Party]] * Creation of an unelected People's Council to oversee political reforms{{cite news|title=Thailand: Seven hurt as gunmen fire on Bangkok protest|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-25694630|work=BBC News|accessdate=13 Thailand * [[2014 Thai coup d'état]] against the [[caretaker government]] * Junta established | side1 = {{bulleted list|[[People's Democratic Reform Committee (PDRC)|People's Democratic Reform Committee]]|[[Democrat Party (Thailand)|Democrat Party]]|}} | side2 = {{bulleted list|[[Yingluck cabinet]]|[[Pheu Thai Party]]|[[United Front for Democracy Against Dictatorship]] ("Red Shirts")}} | leadfigures1 = [[Suthep Thaugsuban]] | leadfigures2 = [[Yingluck Shinawatra]]
[[Niwatthamrong Boonsongpaisan]] (Acting Prime Minister) | howmany3 = | casualties1 = | casualties2 = | fatalities = 28{{Citation |url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/opinion/opinion/410014/cool-heads-must-prevail |title= Cool heads must prevail |newspaper=Bangkok Post |date=16 May 2014}}(as of 16 May 2014) | injuries = 825(as of 16 May 2014){{Citation needed|date=May 2014}} | arrests = 12{{cite news|title=Clashes and casualties|url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/politics/Clashes-and-casualties-30224410.html|accessdate=16 January 2014|newspaper=The Nation|date=16 January 2014}}(as of 16 January 2014) | detentions = | charged = | fined = | casualties_label = | notes = }} [[File:Bangkok protests at the Democracy Memorial in 2013.jpg|thumb|Protests at the Democracy Memorial]] {{Politics of Thailand}} The '''2013–2014 Thai political crisis''' was a period of political instability in [[Thailand]]. Anti-government protests took place between November 2013 and May 2014, organised by the [[People's Democratic Reform Committee]] (PDRC), a political pressure group led by former [[Democrat Party (Thailand)|Democrat Party]] [[House of Representatives (Thailand)|parliamentary representative]] ([[Member of parliament|MP]]) [[Suthep Thaugsuban]].{{cite news|title=Suthep declares 'people's revolt'|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/politics/382361/suthep-declares-people-revolt|accessdate=14 January 2014|newspaper=Bangkok Post|date=30 November 2013}} The protests eventually resulted in the removal of incumbent Prime Minister [[Yingluck Shinawatra]], a [[2014 Thai coup d'état|coup d'état]], and the establishment of the [[National Council for Peace and Order|military junta]]. The primary aim of the protests was the removal of former prime minister [[Thaksin Shinawatra]]'s [[Thaksinocracy|influence]] on Thai politics and the creation of an unelected "people's council" to oversee reforms of the political system.{{cite news|title=Thai protest leader explains demand for 'people's council'|url=http://www.china.org.cn/world/2013-12/04/content_30797670.htm|accessdate=31 May 2014|newspaper=China.org.cn|date=4 December 2013}} Protesters viewed Thaksin as corrupt and damaging to Thailand's democracy,{{cite news|last=Young|first=Jeffrey Young|title=Turmoil in Thailand - Corruption and a Political Struggle|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/turmoil-in-thailand-corruption-and-a-political-struggle/1857954.html|accessdate=30 May 2014|work=Voice of America|date=24 February 2014}}{{cite news|last=Jones|first=Aidan|title=Thaksin corruption claims stoke Thai protest outrage|url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/politics/Thaksin-corruption-claims-stoke-Thai-protest-outra-30224822.html|accessdate=30 May 2014|newspaper=The Nation|date=21 January 2014}} although he enjoyed strong support in many areas of Thailand, particularly the poorer [[Northern Thailand|north]] and [[Isan|northeast]], due to his reforming social programs and economic policies.{{cite news|last=Stout|first=David|title=Popular But Ruthless|url=http://world.time.com/2013/11/07/thailands-color-war-why-red-hates-yellow/slide/thaksin-shinawatra/|accessdate=30 May 2014|newspaper=Time|date=7 November 2013}} Political parties allied to Thaksin had won a majority in every election since 2001. Other issues, such as the [[1924 Palace Law of Succession|royal succession]],{{cite news |author=Mark Fenn |title=Thailand on the Brink|url=http://thediplomat.com/2014/01/thailand-on-the-brink/2/|accessdate=28 March 2014|newspaper=The Diplomat|date=10 January 2014}}{{cite news|title=Where is Thailand heading after protests?|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-26467100|accessdate=28 March 2014|work=BBC News|date=7 March 2014}}{{cite news|title=The path to the throne|url=https://www.economist.com/news/asia/21602759-sudden-move-army-brings-only-near-term-calm-path-throne|work=The Economist|accessdate=30 May 2014|date=24 May 2014}} a rural-urban or north-south divide,{{cite web|last=Bagenal|first=Flora|title=How the Urban-Rural Divide Became a Street War in Bangkok|url=http://nextcity.org/daily/entry/how-the-urban-rural-divide-became-a-street-war-in-bangkok|work=Next City|accessdate=30 May 2014}}{{cite news|title=You go your way, I’ll go mine|url=https://www.economist.com/news/asia/21594989-thailands-very-unity-now-under-threat-you-go-your-way-ill-go-mine|accessdate=31 May 2014|newspaper=The Economist|date=25 January 2014}} social inequality,{{cite web|last1=Mith|first1=Samak|title=Thailand’s Democracy Under Siege|url=http://thediplomat.com/2014/07/thailands-democracy-under-siege/|work=The Diplomat|accessdate=27 July 2014}} over-centralised bureaucracy,{{cite news|last=Boonmi|first=Thirayuth|title=Centralised governance the root of Thailand's woes|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/opinion/opinion/375053/centralised-governance-the-root-of-thailand-woes|accessdate=30 May 2014|newspaper=Bangkok Post|date=17 October 2013}}{{cite news|last=Rojanaphruk|first=Pravit|title=Centralisation of power 'behind social ills'|url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/politics/Centralisation-of-power-behind-social-ills-30211548.html|accessdate=30 May 2014|newspaper=The Nation|date=31 July 2013}} royal and military influence in politics{{cite news |author=Shawn W Crispin |title=No deal behind Thailand's polls|url=http://www.atimes.com/atimes/Southeast_Asia/SEA-02-300114.html|accessdate=28 March 2014|newspaper=Asia Times Online|date=30 January 2014}}{{cite news |author=Brian Rex |title=Thai princess uses social media to 'declare war': Photos posted by Princess Chulabhorn Mahidol widely interpreted as a sign of her support for anti-government protesters|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/thai-princess-uses-social-media-to-declare-war-photos-posted-by-princess-chulabhorn-mahidol-widely-interpreted-as-a-sign-of-her-support-for-antigovernment-protesters-9122267.html|accessdate=28 March 2014|newspaper=The Independent|date=11 February 2014|location=London}}{{cite news |author=Thongchai Winichakul |title=The Antidemocratic Roots of the Thai Protesters |work=Al Jazeera America |date=26 December 2013 |url=http://america.aljazeera.com/opinions/2013/12/the-antidemocraticrootsofthethaiprotesters.html}}{{cite news|title=Powerful forces revealed behind Thai protest movement|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/12/13/us-thailand-protest-military-idUSBRE9BC0PB20131213|accessdate=28 March 2014|agency=Reuters|date=13 December 2013}} and class conflict{{cite web|last=Vorng|first=Sophorntavy|title=Status City: Consumption, Identity, and Middle Class Culture in Contemporary Bangkok|url=http://asiancorrespondent.com/27177/reference-of-the-day-thai-urban-middle-class-and-urban-rural-divide/|work=Asian Correspondent|accessdate=30 May 2014}}{{cite journal|last=Saxer|first=Marc|title=How Thailand’s Middle Class Rage Threatens Democracy|journal=Social Europe Journal|date=23 January 2014|url=http://www.social-europe.eu/2014/01/thailands-middle-class/|accessdate=30 May 2014}} were seen as factors behind the crisis by analysts and commentators. The protests were first triggered by a proposed blanket amnesty bill that would have pardoned several politicians from various charges since 2004, including Thaksin, Suthep Thaugsuban, and [[Abhisit Vejjajiva]]. Opposition from across the political spectrum, including the pro-government [[Red Shirts (Thailand)|Red Shirt movement]], caused the bill to be rejected unanimously by the [[Senate of Thailand]]. Anti-government protests continued however, with demonstrators occupying government offices, blocking major road intersections and holding mass rallies in [[Bangkok]] to call for the resignation of Yingluck Shinawatra, the sister of Thaksin, and her [[Pheu Thai Party|Pheu Thai]] government. On 8 December 2013, all 153 opposition Democrat Party [[Member of Parliament|MPs]] resigned and Yingluck dissolved the [[House of Representatives of Thailand|House of Representatives]], calling a snap [[Thai general election, 2014|general election]] for 2 February.{{cite news|title=Thai prime minister dissolves parliament|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/asia-pacific/2013/12/thai-pm-says-she-will-dissolve-parliament-201312913831169537.html|accessdate=15 December 2013|work=Al Jazeera|date=9 December 2013}} Voting was disrupted in areas of Bangkok and [[southern Thailand]] by PDRC protesters blocking entry to polling stations, leading to an annulment of the result by the [[Constitutional Court of Thailand|Constitutional Court]].{{cite web | url = https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-26677772 | title = Thai court rules general election invalid | work= BBC | date = 21 March 2014 | accessdate = 21 March 2014}} Sporadic violence, including shootings, bomb attempts and grenades thrown at protesters led to 28 deaths and over 800 injuries during the course of the protests. On 21 January, Yingluck's government declared a state of emergency in Bangkok and the surrounding areas, to little effect. Yingluck and nine ministers were removed from office by the Constitutional Court on 7 May 2014 over the [[#Request for removal of Yingluck from office|controversial transfer]] of a senior security officer in 2011.{{cite news|title=Yingluck, 9 ministers removed from office|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/politics/408549/yingluck-9-ministers-removed-from-office|accessdate=22 May 2014|newspaper=Bangkok Post|date=7 May 2014}} Supporters of Yingluck and critics argued that the move was politically motivated and an abuse of judicial power.{{cite news|title=Experts Decry 'Judicial Coup' Against Yingluck|url=http://en.khaosod.co.th/detail.php?newsid=1399546938§ion=11|accessdate=30 May 2014|newspaper=Khaosod English|date=7 May 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140515015617/http://en.khaosod.co.th/detail.php?newsid=1399546938§ion=11|archive-date=15 May 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|last=Brennan|first=Elliot|title=Thai PM removed by judicial coup: What now?|url=http://www.lowyinterpreter.org/post/2014/05/08/Thai-PM-removed-by-Judicial-Coup-What-Now.aspx?COLLCC=2966956618&|accessdate=30 May 2014|newspaper=The Interpreter|date=8 May 2014}}{{cite news|last=Bello|first=Walden|title=Military coup follows judicial coup in Thailand|url=http://opinion.inquirer.net/74896/military-coup-follows-judicial-coup-in-thailand|accessdate=30 May 2014|newspaper=The Inquirer|date=24 May 2014}} On 20 May, the [[Royal Thai Army]] declared [[martial law]] throughout the nation, followed two days later by a coup which removed the government and named General [[Prayut Chan-o-cha]] as acting prime minister.{{cite web | script-title=th:'ประยุทธ์-เหล่าทัพ'แถลง'ควบคุมอำนาจรัฐ' |trans-title=Prayuth and military chiefs control state powers | url = http://www.komchadluek.net/detail/20140522/185160.html | date = 22 May 2014 | accessdate = 22 May 2014 | language = Thai | work= Komchadluek }} The political crisis raised fears of a violent response from supporters of Thaksin, who felt disenfranchised after the governments they had elected in the prior five general elections were removed before completing their terms.{{cite news|last=Blake|first=Chris|title=Thai Coup Risks Clashes as Thaksin Camp Better Organized|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-05-22/thai-coup-risks-deadly-clashes-as-thaksin-camp-better-organized.html|accessdate=30 May 2014|work=Bloomberg|date=23 May 2014}}{{cite news|last=Marshall|first=Andrew MacGregor|title=Is troubled Thailand tumbling into civil war?|url=http://america.aljazeera.com/opinions/2014/5/thailand-crisis-coupthaksinroyalsuccessionmedia.html|accessdate=31 May 2014|work=Al Jazeera|date=23 May 2014}}{{cite news|last=Daniel|first=Zoe|title=No one blameless as Thailand faces civil unrest|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-05-23/daniel-no-one-blameless-as-thailand-faces-civil-unrest/5473322|accessdate=31 May 2014|work=ABC News|date=23 May 2014}} ==Background== The government of Yingluck came to power in the [[Thai general election, 2011|2011 elections]], in which her Pheu Thai Party won an outright majority. Yingluck is a sister of former prime minister Thaksin, and the Pheu Thai Party is closely aligned with him. Thaksin, who was ousted in a [[2006 Thai coup d'état|2006 coup d'état]], lives in self-imposed exile to avoid a 2008 corruption conviction and still commands popular support across much of the country, especially among rural Thais and the urban poor.{{cite news|title=Thai Senate rejects amnesty bill as opposition mounts|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/News/World/2013/11/12/Thai-Senate-rejects-amnesty-bill-as-opposition-mounts.aspx/|accessdate=29 April 2014|newspaper=The Star Online|date=12 November 2013}}{{Cite web|url = http://www.dandc.eu/en/article/almost-year-after-putsch-thailand-military-clings-power|title = Thai-style democracy|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = In: D+C, Vol.42.2015:5|last = Dombrowski|first = Katja}} The Shinawatra family is especially revered in the rural northeast due to the economic and social gains from [[Thaksinomics]]: between 2001 and 2011, [[Isan]]'s GDP per capita more than doubled to US$1,475, while, over the same period, GDP in the Bangkok area soared from US$7,900 to nearly US$13,000.{{cite news|title=Thai northeast vows poll payback to Shinawatra clan|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/thai-northeast-vows-poll/975082.html|accessdate=8 February 2014|agency=Agence France-Presse|date=31 January 2014|author=Aidan Jones}} Several amnesty proposals and amendments to the constitution had been debated by the House of Representatives during Yingluck's premiership. Most of these were popularly perceived as benefiting Thaksin, and were opposed by the Democrat Party. In August 2013, the Pheu Thai-majority House approved a first reading of a draft amnesty bill.{{cite news|author1=Mongkol Bangprapa |author2=Manop Thip Osod |author3=Aekarach Sattaburuth| title=Amnesty bill cruises first reading|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/local/363733/amnesty-bill-cruises-first-reading|accessdate=24 November 2013|newspaper=Bangkok Post|date=9 August 2013}} Street protests leading up to the parliamentary session were held by an anti-Thaksin group calling itself the "People's Democratic Force to Overthrow Thaksinism" (PEFOT), as well as by the Democrat Party, but these failed to gain momentum.{{cite news |author=Thitinan Pongsudhirak|title=Street rallies yield to parliamentary process|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/opinion/opinion/363747/street-rallies-yield-to-parliamentary-process|accessdate=24 November 2013|newspaper=Bangkok Post|date=9 August 2013}} The amnesty bill was handed over to a 35-member scrutinising committee, after which it would be returned to the House for second and third readings. The committee passed a revised draft of the bill on 18 October 2013.{{cite news |author=Mongkol Bangprapa |title=Amnesty bill revision slammed|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/breakingnews/375261/panel-passes-tweaked-amnesty-bill|accessdate=24 November 2013|newspaper=Bangkok Post|date=18 October 2013}} The bill, which in its original form was aimed to absolve civilian protesters, excluding protest and government leaders and the military, was drastically expanded into a "blanket amnesty", covering the period from 2004 to 2013. This would have included the corruption charges laid against Thaksin during the 2006 coup, as well as the murder charges against Abhisit and Suthep over their conduct of the [[2010 Thai political protests|2010 mass protests]] in support of Thaksin. ==Timeline of the events== {{Overly detailed|date=May 2014|section=yes}} ===Protests against amnesty bill=== [[File:ManifestBKK01.jpg|thumb|left|Protesters near the Democracy Monument in Bangkok, November 2013]] The bill was passed by the Pheu Thai Party–dominated House of Representatives on 1 November 2013 at around 04:00.{{cite news|last=Campbell |first=Charlie |url=http://world.time.com/2013/11/01/thailands-amnesty-bill-unites-political-foes-against-government/ |title=Thailand's Amnesty Bill Unites Political Foes Against Government |work=Time|date=1 November 2013 |accessdate=13 May 2014}} The final draft of the bill would have pardoned protesters involved in various incidents of political unrest since 2004, dismissed Thaksin's corruption convictions, and annulled murder charges against Abhisit and Suthep.{{cite news|title=Insight: How Thaksin's meddling sparked a new Thai crisis for PM sister|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/01/31/us-thailand-amnesty-insight-idUSBREA0U00620140131|accessdate=2 May 2014|agency=Reuters|date=30 January 2014}}{{cite news|title=Ex-Thai PM Abhisit and Former Deputy Charged With Murder|work=Time|url=http://world.time.com/2013/10/29/ex-thai-pm-abhisit-and-former-deputy-charged-with-murder/|accessdate=16 January 2014|date=29 October 2013}}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The bill sparked opposition from both the Democrat Party and the pro-government Red Shirt movement.{{cite news|title=Thailand: anti-Thaksin protesters set new targets after amnesty bill defeat|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/nov/12/thailand-anti-thaksin-protesters-amnesty-bill-defeat|accessdate=13 January 2014|newspaper=The Guardian|date=12 November 2013}} Criticism was levelled at the government for passing the vote in the unusual pre-dawn session to prevent opposition. Thaksin's opponents protested against absolving Thaksin of his convictions. Thaksin supporters criticised the bill for absolving those responsible for the crackdown on the 2010 protests. On 4 November 2013, several protests took place in Bangkok, as well as in several provincial cities. Several universities and organisations issued statements condemning the bill. However, an independent poll conducted between 11–13 November reported that the majority of surveyed Thai people wanted the protests to end.{{cite news|title=Poll: Most want an end to protests|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/politics/379620/people-fed-up-with-political-protests-suan-dusit-poll-reveals|accessdate=12 January 2014|newspaper=Bangkok Post|date=13 November 2013}} Faced with strong opposition, Yingluck issued a statement, urging the Senate to contemplate the bill with the interests of the people in mind. (Procedurally, the House could not recall the bill after voting; the decision lay with the Senate.) Pheu Thai Party leaders also promised not to revive the bill, or any other amnesty bills, if it was rejected by the Senate. The Senate subsequently voted on the bill on 11 November 2013, unanimously rejecting it.{{cite news|author=Mongkol Bangprapa |title=Senators shoot down blanket amnesty bill|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/local/379319/senators-reject-amnesty-bill|accessdate=24 November 2013|newspaper=Bangkok Post|date=12 November 2013}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-25127436 |title=Thailand protests day four: Momentum builds in Bangkok |work=BBC News |date=27 November 2013}} At the same time, the [[International Court of Justice]] confirmed Cambodia's sovereignty over [[Cambodian–Thai border dispute|disputed territory]] near the [[Preah Vihear Temple]], prompting fears of further political tension from analysts, although the border remained calm. Despite the amnesty bill being dropped, protests in Bangkok continued. Suthep and eight other Democrat members of parliament resigned from their positions to lead demonstrations, calling for the general populace to strike and undertake civil disobedience.{{cite news|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/politics/379322|title=Suthep resigns to head up civil disobedience |newspaper=Bangkok Post |date=12 November 2013|accessdate=1 December 2013}} The protests gradually shifted towards an anti-government agenda, criticising Yingluck and her government for being proxies for Thaksin and being an [[elective dictatorship]]. Several groups protested, including Suthep's Civil Movement for Democracy, the Green Politics group, the Network of Students and People for Reform of Thailand (NSPRT), PEFOT, the Dhamma Army, and the State Enterprises Workers' Relations Confederation. Whistle blowing became a symbol of the protests.{{cite news |author=Nopparat Chaichalearmmongkol|title=Whistle Blowers Call Time Out on Amnesty Bill|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/searealtime/2013/11/07/whistle-blowers-call-time-out-on-amnesty-bill/|accessdate=1 December 2013|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|date=7 November 2013}}{{efn|Note that the [[People's Alliance for Democracy]] (PAD), or "Yellow Shirts", which led protests in 2006 and 2008 had since largely declined in popularity and influence. While there was substantial overlap between the 2013 anti-government protesters and the former PAD, the 2013 protesters did not wear yellow.}} === Constitutional amendment === [[File:2013.15-18 Constitutional Court Decision.jpg|right|300px|thumb|The first and last pages of the Constitutional Court's decision with the signatures of the judges]] {{wikisource|Constitutional Court Decision No. 15–18/2556}} On 20 November 2013, the [[Constitutional Court of Thailand|Constitutional Court]] invalidated a government-proposed amendment to the [[2007 Constitution of Thailand|2007 constitution]],{{cite news|title=Politics-Thailand: New Constitution Regressive Say Critics|url=http://www.ipsnews.net/2007/04/politics-thailand-new-constitution-regressive-say-critics/|accessdate=4 February 2014|newspaper=IPS News|date=23 April 2007}}{{cite news|last=Corben|first=Ron|title=Draft constitution faces uphill battle in Thailand|url=http://atimes.com/atimes/Southeast_Asia/ID25Ae01.html|accessdate=4 February 2014|newspaper=Asia Times Online|date=25 April 2007}} which would have restored elements of the [[Constitution of the Kingdom of Thailand, Buddhist Era 2540 (1997)|1997 "People's" constitution]]. The major alteration would have been the restoration of a fully elected Senate. The court found that both the proceedings of the amendment and the contents of the new version were unconstitutional. The court ruled that the final draft voted on by the National Assembly was not the same as the one originally considered, and the new draft was brought to the sessions without an introductory motion. The court also decided that the time limit for amending the draft (which left only one day for the filing of amendments) was unlawful, and many MPs were found to have voted on behalf of absent MPs. With regard to the contents, the court said the amendment would have allowed the relatives of the representatives to become senators, weakening the ability of the Senate to scrutinise the House of Representatives. The 1997 constitution did not prohibit relatives of representatives becoming senators and resulted in the National Assembly gaining the infamous nickname "Assembly of Husbands and Wives" (สภาผัวเมีย). The court also held that the conversion of the Senate into a fully elected chamber would destroy the [[Bicameralism|bicameral system]].{{cite news | title = Thai Court Rules Against Constitution Amendment | work = The Wall Street Journal | date = 20 November 2013 | accessdate = 31 January 2014 | author = Warangkana Chomchuen | url = https://www.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702303653004579209584204486364}}{{cite web | title = Constitutional Court says charter amendments unconstitutional | work = The Nation | date = 20 November 2013 | accessdate = 31 January 2014 | url = http://www.nationmultimedia.com/politics/Constitutional-Court-says-charter-amendments-uncon-30220104.html#sthash.kGJomifp.dpuf}} In its decision, the court stated:{{cite journal | script-title=th:คำวินิจฉัยศาลรัฐธรรมนูญที่ 15–18/2556 |trans-title=Constitutional Court Decision No. 15–18/2556 | language = Thai | format = PDF | journal = [[Royal Thai Government Gazette|Government Gazette]] | issue = 5 A | volume = 131 | pages = 1–132 | url = http://www.ratchakitcha.soc.go.th/DATA/PDF/2557/A/005/1.PDF | publisher = Cabinet Secretariat | location = Bangkok}}
The constitutional amendment pursuant to the petitions is a return to the former defects which are perilous and likely to bring an end to the faith and harmony of the majority of the Thai people. It is an attempt to draw the Nation back into the canal, as it would bring the Senate back to the state of being an assembly of relatives, assembly of family members and assembly of husbands and wives. In consequence, the Senate would lose its status and vigour as the source of wisdom for the House of Representatives, but would merely be an echo of the people from the same group. The principles of the bicameral system would be debased, leading to the monopoly of state powers and the exclusion of the participation of the members of various sectors and professions. The amendment is thus an effort of its initiators to regain the national government power by the means not recognised by the Constitution [...]
[[Chulalongkorn University]] Dean of Law Nantawat Boramanand viewed the statement as an expression of disapproval towards the Pheu Thai-dominated House.{{cite web | script-title=th:บ้านเมืองที่ไร้กติกา |trans-title=Land without rules | author = Nantawat Boramanand | publisher = Pub-Law | date = 15 December 2013 | accessdate = 31 January 2014 | language = Thai | url = http://www.pub-law.net/publaw/view.aspx?id=1913}}{{Citation needed|reason=need at least one or two more experts|date=April 2014}} The court held that it was competent to deal with the case to provide [[checks and balances]] to the principles of [[separation of powers]]. Some legal scholars argued that the court could not interfere with the constitutional amendment, as the National Assembly was not exercising the [[legislative power]], but the constituent power which is not subject to the system of checks and balances between the [[Checks and balances|three branches]].{{cite web | script-title=th:ศาลรัฐธรรมนูญไม่มีอำนาจวินิจฉัยร่างแก้ไขเพิ่มเติม รธน. สมลักษณ์ จัดกระบวนพล อดีตผู้พิพากษาศาลฎีกา อดีตกรรมการป.ป.ช. และอาจารย์พิเศษผู้บรรยายวิชาระบบศาลและการพิจารณาคดี (พระธรรมนูญศาลยุติธรรม) คณะนิติศาสตร์ มหาวิทยาลัยธรรมศาสตร์ โต้แย้ง |trans-title=Charter court incompetent to decide on constitutional amendment, said Somlak Chadkrabuanpol, former Supreme Court judge, former NACC member and Thammasat lecturer in judicial systems and court constitution | url = http://www.khaosod.co.th/view_newsonline.php?newsid=TVRNNE56YzVNelk1Tnc9PQ== | language = Thai | work= Khaosod | date = 23 December 2013 | accessdate = 31 January 2014}}{{cite web | script-title=th:วรเจตน์ ภาคีรัตน์: วินิจฉัยโดยไม่มีอำนาจ ความน่าเอือมระอาของศาลรัฐธรรมนูญ |trans-title=Worachet Pakeerut: Rule without power – Weariness caused by Charter Court | url = http://prachatai.com/journal/2014/01/51032 | language = Thai | work= Prachatai | author = Phinphaka Ngamsom and Bandit Ueawatthananukun | date = 9 January 2014 | accessdate = 31 January 2014}}{{cite web | script-title=th:'เอกชัย' ยัน ศาล รธน. ไม่มีอำนาจวินิจฉัยแก้ รธน. |trans-title=Instructor Ekkachai insists, charter court incompetent to rule on constitutional amendment | url = http://www.bangkokbiznews.com/home/detail/politics/analysis/20131121/544811/%E0%B9%80%E0%B8%AD%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%8A%E0%B8%B1%E0%B8%A2%E0%B8%A2%E0%B8%B1%E0%B8%99%E0%B8%A8%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%A5%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%98%E0%B8%99.%E0%B9%84%E0%B8%A1%E0%B9%88%E0%B8%A1%E0%B8%B5%E0%B8%AD%E0%B8%B3%E0%B8%99%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%88%E0%B8%A7%E0%B8%B4%E0%B8%99%E0%B8%B4%E0%B8%88%E0%B8%89%E0%B8%B1%E0%B8%A2%E0%B9%81%E0%B8%81%E0%B9%89%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%98%E0%B8%99..html | language = Thai | work= Bangkok Biz | date = 21 November 2013 | accessdate = 31 January 2014}} The Pheu Thai Party rejected the decision, claiming that the court had no jurisdiction over the case,{{cite news|title=312 MPs, senators reject Constitution Court's decision before it's made|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/politics/380642/senators-mps-defy-constitution-court-ahead-of-decision|accessdate=12 January 2014|newspaper=Bangkok Post|date=19 November 2013}} earning the Constitutional Court the nickname "San Khrai Fang" (ศาลใครฟัง; "court heeded by no one").{{cite web | script-title=th:ม.เกษตรฯ ตั้งฉายาการเมืองปี 56 | url = http://www.thairath.co.th/content/pol/389484 | work= Thairath| date = 17 December 2013 | accessdate = 17 December 2013 | language = Thai}} Although her party ignored the court decision and asserted the legality of the draft amendment, Yingluck withdrew the draft from King [[Bhumibol Adulyadej]] on 8 December 2013 before the King signed it into law.{{cite web | script-title=th:นายกฯ ขอพระบรมราชานุญาตถอนร่างแก้ไขรธนที่มา สว. แล้ว |trans-title=PM withdrew the draft constitution amendment on senatorial instatement from the King | date = 8 December 2013 | accessdate = 8 December 2013 |work= [[ThaiPBS]] | language = Thai | url =http://news.thaipbs.or.th/content/%E0%B8%99%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%A2%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%AF%E0%B8%82%E0%B8%AD%E0%B8%9E%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B0%E0%B8%9A%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%A1%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%8A%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%99%E0%B8%B8%E0%B8%8D%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%95-%E0%B8%96%E0%B8%AD%E0%B8%99%E0%B8%A3%E0%B9%88%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%87%E0%B9%81%E0%B8%81%E0%B9%89%E0%B9%84%E0%B8%82%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%98%E0%B8%99%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%B5%E0%B9%88%E0%B8%A1%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%AA%E0%B8%A7%E0%B9%81%E0%B8%A5%E0%B9%89%E0%B8%A7}} The Pheu Thai Party's denial of the court decision resulted in anti-government protest numbers swelling over the following weekend of 23–24 November 2013, with at least 100,000 protesters gathering at the [[Democracy Monument]] on [[Ratchadamnoen Avenue]]. Protest leaders claimed up to a million people joined the rally. The UDD-led Red Shirts, who had reconciled with the government after the amnesty bill was dropped and had been rallying its supporters at [[Rajamangala Stadium]] prior to the court decision, also resumed their counter-protest, with about 40,000 supporters arriving on 24 November.{{cite news|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/local/381488/|title=Tens of thousands join anti-government rally |date=24 November 2013 |newspaper=Bangkok Post|accessdate=1 December 2013}} The National Anti-Corruption Commission (NACC) ruled on 7 January 2014 that it cleared 73 politicians, including Yingluck, in relation to the unsuccessful bid to create a fully elected senate. However, 308 others from the upper and lower houses were found to be in violation of Thai law. The announcement was only based on a preliminary investigation, but if the 308 members were officially found guilty by the commission, they could be banned from politics for five years by the upper house of the National Assembly, which would make the final decision on their cases.{{cite news|title=Thai anti-graft panel to charge hundreds of MPs|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/thai-anti-graft-panel-to/945986.html|accessdate=8 January 2014|work=Channel NewsAsia|date=7 January 2014}} ===Seizure of government buildings=== [[File:Protesters on motorcycles in Bangkok, 1 December 2013.jpg|thumb|Protesters mobilising on 1 December]] [[File:Demonstration at the Ministry of Labour in Bangkok.jpg|thumb|Demonstration at the Ministry of Labour, Bangkok]] On 25 November 2013, anti-government protesters from the People's Democratic Reform Committee led by Suthep began marched to several government offices and forced their way inside the [[Ministry of Finance (Thailand)|Ministry of Finance]], the Budget Bureau, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and the Public Relations Department, forcing their closure without police intervention, due to government fears that this could result in a repeat 2006 military coup. Yingluck invoked the [[Internal Security Act (Thailand)|Internal Security Act]] (ISA) in all districts of Bangkok and [[Nonthaburi Province]], and the [[Bang Phli District|Bang Phli]] and [[Lat Lum Kaeo District|Lat Lum Kaeo]] Districts of [[Samut Prakan Province|Samut Prakan]] and [[Pathum Thani Province|Pathum Thani]] Provinces respectively.{{cite news|title=Protesters storm key ministries|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/local/381680/protesters-storm-key-ministries|accessdate=1 December 2013|newspaper=Bangkok Post|date=26 November 2013}} (This was in addition to the central districts of Bangkok, where the ISA had been in effect since the previous month.) However, no direct confrontations between the protesters and security authorities occurred. The protesters continued on 27 November by rallying outside another ten ministry offices, cutting off electricity and forcing the evacuation of the [[Department of Special Investigation]]'s headquarters, and staging a sit-in at the [[Chaeng Watthana Government Complex]]. Protesters also rallied at twenty-four provincial halls, mainly in the south, a traditional Democrat Party base of support.{{cite news|author=Amy Sawitta Lefevre |title=Thai protesters move on more ministries; central bank cuts rates|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2013/11/27/uk-thailand-protest-idUKBRE9AQ05M20131127|accessdate=1 December 2013|date=27 November 2013|agency=Reuters}} Protesters broke into the offices of state-owned telecommunications companies [[CAT Telecom|CAT]] and [[TOT Public Company|TOT]] on 30 November, disrupting internet services for several hours.{{cite news |author1=Warangkana Chomchuen |author2=Wilawan Watcharasakwet|title=Two Killed in Thai Clashes, Protesters Vow to Storm State Buildings|url=https://www.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702303562904579229782754803164|accessdate=1 December 2013|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|date=1 December 2013}} The protests had been peaceful{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-25149484 |title=BBC News - What is behind Thailand's political turmoil? |work=BBC |date=7 May 2014 |accessdate=13 May 2014}} before short violent clashes on 30 November and 1 December 2013. On the night of 1 December, violence erupted between anti-government [[Ramkhamhaeng University]] students and Red Shirt government supporters near Rajamangala Stadium. University students attacked a taxi containing a red shirt supporter. Gunshots were fired at the students, resulting in four deaths and fifty-seven people wounded.{{cite news|title=Updated toll: 4 dead, 57 wounded|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/local/382573/updated-toll-4-dead-57-wounded|accessdate=1 December 2013|newspaper=Bangkok Post|date=1 December 2013}}{{cite news |author1=Piyaporn Wongruang |author2=Manop Thip-Osod |title=One killed as 'V-Day' eve violence erupts |url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/local/382474/one-killed-as-v-day-eve-violence-erupts|accessdate=1 December 2013|newspaper=Bangkok Post|date=1 December 2013 }} The gunman was identified by an eyewitness as a Red Shirt protester, while PDRC core member Sathit Wongnongtoey claimed that "police officers had taken off their uniforms and donned red shirts to attack Ramkhamhaeng students in front of the university".{{cite web|url=http://www.thephuketnews.com/one-killed-as-v-day-eve-violence-erupts-43154.php |title=One killed as 'V-Day' eve violence erupts |work=Phuket News |date=1 December 2013 |accessdate=13 May 2014}} UDD leaders subsequently ended their rally the following morning.{{cite news|title=Red-shirt leaders end rally|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/breakingnews/382511/red-shirt-leaders-end-rally-after-violence|accessdate=1 December 2013|newspaper=Bangkok Post|date=1 December 2013|agency=Agence France-Presse}} [[File:Police barricade at Ministry of Education, Bangkok, 1 December 2013.jpg|thumb|left|Police guarding a barricade, Ministry of Education, 1 December]] Suthep, representing the newly created People's Democratic Reform Committee (PDRC; literal translation of the Thai name: "People's Committee for Complete Democracy with the King as Head of State"{{Citation |url=http://www.khaosod.co.th/en/view_newsonline.php?newsid=TVRNNE5qRTFNekV6TVE9PQ==§ionid=TURVd01BPT0= |title=Govt Slams Suthep's Call For Royal Intervention |newspaper=Khaosod English |date=4 December 2013}}), had vowed to further escalate the protests on 1 December in a "people's coup" attempt. That day protesters tried to force their way into [[Government House of Thailand|Government House]] and the [[Metropolitan Police (Thailand)|Metropolitan Police]] headquarters, but were halted by police using barricades, tear gas, and water cannons. About 2,700 unarmed soldiers were called in to support the police. That afternoon, Yingluck cancelled planned media interviews and moved to an undisclosed location when the building she was in was surrounded by protesters.{{cite news|title=Thailand clashes: PM forced to flee as violent demonstrations escalate|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/dec/01/thailand-protest-yingluck-shinawatra-violence|accessdate=1 December 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=1 December 2013}}{{cite news |author=Amy Sawitta Lefevre |title=Thai protesters step up action, PM forced to leave building|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/12/01/us-thailand-protest-idUSBRE9AT01S20131201|accessdate=1 December 2013|date=1 December 2013|agency=Reuters}} Protesters also entered several television stations, including the [[Thai Public Broadcasting Service]], forcing them to broadcast a public address by Suthep,{{cite web|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/breakingnews/382542/anti-government-protesters-take-control-of-thai-pbs-television-station |title=Protesters take control of Thai PBS |work=Bangkok Post|date=1 December 2013|accessdate=1 December 2013}}{{cite news|title=Thailand police fend off mass protests in Bangkok|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-25174822|accessdate=1 December 2013|work=BBC|date=1 December 2013}} an act condemned by three media organisations.{{cite news|title=Media groups condemn protest threats|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/breakingnews/382598/media-organisations-condemn-protesters-threats|accessdate=1 December 2013|newspaper=Bangkok Post|date=1 December 2013}} In a televised address, Suthep said that protesters had occupied twelve government buildings, but this claim was denied by the national security chief Paradorn Pattanathabutr. Suthep later unilaterally announced that he had met with Prime Minister Yingluck to deliver an ultimatum "to return power to people" within two days. He reaffirmed his stance that Yingluck's resignation or the dissolution of the House of Representatives was not acceptable, and repeated his calls to replace elected officials with an unelected "People's Council" that would choose leaders.{{cite news|title=Suthep gives PM ultimatum before military leaders|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/politics/382604/suthep-gives-pm-ultimatum-before-military-leaders|accessdate=1 December 2013|newspaper=Bangkok Post|date=1 December 2013}} Yingluck had rejected the demands on the basis that suspending the democratic process would be unconstitutional.{{cite web|url=http://worldnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/12/01/21701740-thai-pm-flees-police-compound-as-protesters-launch-peoples-coup-at-least-four-dead |title=Thai PM flees police compound as protesters launch 'people's coup'; at least four dead |work=NBC News |date=1 December 2013 |accessdate=25 March 2014}} On 3 December 2013, the police removed barricades and allowed protesters to enter the site, reducing tensions to allow both sides to celebrate King [[Bhumibol Adulyadej]]'s birthday. ===Electronic attacks=== The ''Digital Attack Map'' website recorded relatively large scale distributed denial of service ([[DDoS]]) attacks against internet services in Thailand corresponding almost directly to the period of demonstrations, 27 November through 20 December 2013. {{cite web|url=http://www.digitalattackmap.com/#anim=1&color=0&country=TH&time=16060.2&view=map|title=DDoS attacks corresponding to protests in Thailand.|date=3 December 2013}} === Government dissolution === After the King's Birthday, Suthep called for protesters to take to the streets and march to Government House on 9 December in a "final battle". The protest was attended by 160,000 people. On 8 December, all 153 minority Democrat MPs jointly resigned in a move seen as trying to pressure further the government.{{cite news |author1=Pradit Ruangdit |author2=Penchan Charoensuthipan|author3=Wassana Nanuam |title=Democrat MPs resign en masse|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/local/383826/democrat-mps-resign-en-masse|accessdate=9 December 2013|newspaper=Bangkok Post|date=9 December 2013}} In response to the intensive protests, Yingluck dissolved the House of Representatives on 9 December 2013 and proposed a [[Thai general election, 2014|general election]] for 2 February 2014, a date that was later approved by the election commission. The PDRC insisted that the prime minister stand down within 24 hours, regardless of her actions. Yingluck insisted that she would continue her duties until the scheduled election in February 2014, urging the protesters to accept her proposal: "Now that the government has dissolved parliament, I ask that you stop protesting and that all sides work towards elections. I have backed down to the point where I don't know how to back down any further."{{cite news|title=Thai PM Urges Protesters to Take Part in Election|url=https://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2013/12/10/world/asia/10reuters-thailand-protest.html?ref=reuters&_r=0|accessdate=15 December 2013|newspaper=New York Times|date=10 December 2013|agency=Reuters}} Yingluck survived a [[no-confidence vote]] in the House of Representatives on 28 November 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/thai-protesters-storm-army-headquarters/1800045.html|title=Thai Protesters Storm Army Headquarters |work=VOA|date=29 November 2013 |accessdate=1 December 2013}} Meanwhile, supporters of the NSPRT claimed the seizure of army headquarters, demanding that the military join the protests.{{cite web|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/local/382363/prayuth-says-army-neutral |title=Prayuth says army neutral |work=Bangkok Post|date=30 November 2013|accessdate=1 December 2013}} In response, on 29 November Army Commander [[Prayut Chan-o-cha]] urged protest groups not to involve the military and called on rival sides to resolve the crisis peacefully. The government abstained from the use of excessive force, relying on [[Baton (law enforcement)|batons]], [[water cannon]]s, and [[tear gas]] instead.{{cite web|url=http://voiceofrussia.com/news/2013_12_01/Thai-Security-Chief-claims-protesters-have-not-seized-state-buildings-2503/ |title=Thai Security Chief claims protesters have not seized state buildings|work=Voice of Russia|date=1 December 2013|accessdate=1 December 2013}} {{clear}} [[File:Suthep Thaugsuban by VOA.jpg|thumbnail|Anti-government protest leader Suthep Thaugsuban, centre, with his wife Srisakul Promphan, in white, arrive at the Democracy Monument, Bangkok, 15 December 2013.]] ===Post-government dissolution=== On 17 December 2013, PDRC secretary Suthep called for rallies with slogans demanding: * Reform before election * Immediate resignation of Yingluck and the cabinet * Establishment of a non-elected People's Council to start a reform process for 12 to 18 months. On 21 December 2013, the Democrat Party announced that it would boycott the February elections.{{cite news|last=Buranakanokthanasan|first=Wirat|title=Thai opposition party to boycott election|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/12/21/us-thailand-protest-idUSBRE9BK04H20131221|accessdate=25 December 2013|agency=Reuters|date=21 December 2013}} In response to the EC's registration process for party-list candidates for the scheduled election in February 2014, anti-government protesters marched to the Thai-Japanese sports stadium, the venue of the registration process, on 22 December 2013. Suthep and the PDRC led the protest, with the former declaring, "If the government and the EC still insist on the election, they are challenging the will of the people". [[File:Anti-government protests in Bangkok at Rajaprasong Intersection, 22.12.2013.jpg|thumb|Anti-government protests at Rajaprasong Intersection, Bangkok, 22 December 2013]]The PDRC estimated that 3.5 million people participated in the march on 22 December, while security forces claimed that approximately 270,000 protesters joined the rally.
