{{Infobox ethnic group |group = Urapmin |population = about 375 |region1 = [[West Sepik Province]], {{flag|Papua New Guinea}} |languages = [[Urapmin language]] |religions = [[Baptist]]<ref name="r1998_308" /> |related = [[Telefol people]], [[Tifal people]] }}
The '''Urapmin people''' are an ethnic group numbering about 375 people in the [[Telefomin District]] of the [[West Sepik Province]] of [[Papua New Guinea]]. One of the [[Mountain Ok people|Min peoples]] who inhabit this area, the Urapmin share the common Min practices of [[hunter-gatherer]] subsistence, [[taro]] cultivation, and formerly, an elaborate secret cult available only to initiated men.
The Urapmin used to ally with the [[Telefol people|Telefolmin]] in war against other Min peoples, practicing [[cannibalism]] against the enemy dead, but warfare ceased by the 1960s with the arrival of [[colonialism]]. A [[Christian revival]] in the 1970s led to the near-complete abandonment of traditional beliefs and the adoption of a form of [[Charismatic Christianity]] originally derived from [[Baptist Christianity]]. The Urapmin vigorously use their native [[Urapmin language|Urap language]], and their small community maintains the practice of [[endogamy]].
== Classification == [[Image:Bilum.jpg|160px|thumb|Bilum string bags are used by the Min peoples of the Telefolmin District in Papua New Guinea.]] The Urapmin are one of the [[Mountain Ok people|Min people]]s, a group of related peoples in [[Papua New Guinea]] who number about thirty thousand in total.<ref name="b28">{{Harvcoltxt|Barker|2007|p=28}}</ref><ref name="m306" /><ref name="mac31" /> Min peoples are mainly found in the [[Telefomin District]], spread from the mountains of the [[Strickland River]] to [[West Papua Province]].<ref name="c609">{{Harvcoltxt|Cranstone|1968|p=609}}</ref><ref name="b332">{{Harvcoltxt|Brumbaugh|1980|p=332}}</ref> The name ''Min'' derives from the suffix ''-min'', meaning 'peoples', which is present in their names (e.g. [[Telefol people|Telefolmin]], [[Wopkaimin people|Wopkaimin]], etc.).<ref name="mac31">{{Harvcoltxt|MacKenzie|1991|p=31}}</ref>
Min peoples may also be known as Mountain Ok peoples, from the word ''ok'' meaning 'river' or 'water'.<ref name="mac31" /> The latter name contrasts them with the [[Lowland Ok people]] to the south who speak related languages but differ greatly culturally and in the environment that they live in.<ref name="mac31" />
The Urapmin speak a [[Mountain Ok languages|Mountain Ok language]].<ref name="b28" /> Although this language family is tied to the Min ethnic grouping, it does not absolutely define the group, since the [[Oksapmin]] to the east and the Om river groups speak non-Mountain Ok languages.<ref name="mac32" /> The Urapmin kinship system is [[cognatic]];<ref name="r2004_24" /> in general the western Min groups have [[bilateral kinship]] systems, while the eastern Min groups have [[patrilineal kinship]] systems.<ref name="mac32" />
The Min peoples are fairly homogeneous in technology, economy, and subsistence.<ref name="mac32" /> This includes hunting and gathering from forests and stream-beds, shifting [[taro]] cultivation, and raising small numbers of domestic pigs.<ref name="mac32" /> Min material culture is also fairly uniform; Telefol women describe [[bilum]]s throughout the Min region as being of "one kind", though there is some stylistic variation.<ref name="mac33">{{Harvcoltxt|MacKenzie|1991|pp=33}}</ref>
A salient shared feature of Min culture is a common origin myth and initiation into a secret male religious cult.<ref name="b332" /><ref name="mac32" /> Traditionally, the Min believed that all Min peoples other than the [[Baktaman]] are children of [[Afek (mythology)|Afek]], the "Primal Mother" and originator of all Min culture and religion.<ref name="mac32-33">{{Harvcoltxt|MacKenzie|1991|pp=32–33}}</ref> The types and number of cult initiation ceremonies differed among different Min groups.<ref name="mac32-33" /> The Telefol in particular were viewed as being guardians of Afek's legacy since they were her lastborn,<ref name="mac33" /> and the Urapmin were close to the Telefol in the Min ritual hierarchy.<ref name="r2004_15,17">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2004|pp=15, 17}}</ref>
== History == [[Image:OkTediMine.jpg|thumb|250px|The [[Ok Tedi mine]] site.]] Historically, the [[Mountain Ok people|Min peoples]] were in a constant state of warfare with one another.<ref name="c610" /> Each Min tribe was a unified group whose component groups did not wage war among each other, with the exception of the [[Tifalmin people]] who were split into four mutually hostile groups.<ref name="c610" /> The primary weapon used in war was a [[bow and arrow|bow]] of black [[palm wood]], usually using arrows with barbed wooden heads.<ref name="c610" />
Spears were unknown, though some tribes (e.g. the Telefolmin, but not the Tifalmin) used wooden clubs.<ref name="c610" /> Warfare might consist either of small ambush parties, which would surprise people on paths and in gardens and kill and [[cannibalism|eat]] all of those caught, no matter their age or sex.<ref name="c610" /> Other times, warfare was more formal, with groups marching out to meet each other for battle with freshly-painted shields.<ref name="c610" />
The Urapmin divided up peoples encountered into traditional allies ([[Urapmin language|Urap]]: ''dup'') and enemies (''wasi''), along with foreigners (''ananang'').<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2004|p=88}}</ref> The Urapmin were allied with the Telefolmin, and engaged in trade with them, and in war joined with them to become a single unit.<ref name="c618">{{Harvcoltxt|Cranstone|1968|p=618}}</ref><ref name="b333">{{Harvcoltxt|Brumbaugh|1980|p=333}}</ref> This was based in the belief in descent from common ancestors.<ref name="c610" /> The Urapmin also were friendly with their southern neighbors, the [[Faiwolmin people|Faiwolmin]].<ref name="c610" />
Friendly relations with foreign groups were based on [[trade]] — the Urapmin practiced a custom whereby men would have ''tisol dup'' (literally "wealth friend"), trading partners from other Mountain Ok groups.<ref name="r2004_51">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2004|p=51}}</ref> The Telefol and Urapmin were traditionally enemies with the Tifalmin to the northwest and the [[Feranmin]] to the southeast.<ref name="mac32">{{Harvcoltxt|MacKenzie|1991|p=32}}</ref> Warfare was still practiced between the Min peoples in the first half of the twentieth century.<ref name="c610" />
=== European contact === European contact came late to Papua New Guinea, and to the [[New Guinea Highlands|Highlands]] in particular.<ref name="r2004_46">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2004|p=46}}</ref> While the European contact with the Telefolmin dates to 1914, the earliest European contact with the Urapmin was made by the Williams party of 1936–1937, which was searching the [[Fly River|Fly]] and [[Sepik River|Sepik]] areas for mineral deposits.<ref name="r2004_49">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2004|p=49}}</ref> Led by an [[United States|American]] by the name of Ward Williams, the party consisted of eight (later nine) Europeans and twenty-three natives recruited from the coast.<ref name="r2004_49" /> The Williams group had minimal contact with the Urapmin.<ref name="r2004_50">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2004|p=50}}</ref>
Urapmin who were alive at the time attest that the Urapmin, unsure how to refer to the newcomers, learned from the Telefolmin to refer to them as the ''Wilumin'', a [[portmanteau]] of the name 'William' and the suffix used for [[demonyms]] among the Min peoples, ''-min''.<ref name="r2004_50" /><ref group="nb">The Urapmin later abandoned this term and began calling the whites ''dalabal'', meaning the smell of a [[penis gourd]]. Eventually the coastal natives that were hired by another patrol taught the Urapmin the term ''tabalasep'', which is the term that is currently used in the Urap language for whites. See {{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2004|p=50}}.</ref> A trade relationship was quickly established, with [[salt]] being the most desired commodity among the Urapmin.<ref name="r2004_51" /> The Urapmin relate that:
{{Quote | text=We were afraid when we first saw whites, but they enticed us with salt. We tasted it and it was good. And then they gave us matches and showed us how to make fires. Then we went and got them food, sweet potato, taro, and bananas and we gave it to them. We exchanged.<ref>Babalok, a member of the Urapmin, quoted in {{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2004|p=51}}</ref>}}
In 1944, the [[Australian]]s built up the [[airstrip]] in [[Telefomin]] for use by the [[Allies of World War II|Allied Forces]] as an emergency landing strip in the [[New Guinea campaign]] of [[World War II]].<ref name="r2004_53">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2004|p=53}}</ref> From this point until the end of the war, the [[Australian New Guinea Administrative Unit]] kept a post in Telefomin, though it is unclear to what extent this affected the Urapmin at the time.<ref name="r2004_53" /> In 1948, after the conclusion of the war, a patrol station was established at Telefomin, marking the beginning of Australian colonization of the region.<ref name="r2004_53" />
The Urapmin refer to the subsequent colonial period as the time when "the law came and got us" ([[Tok Pisin]]: ''lo i kam kisim mipela'') or when "we got the law" (Tok Pisin: ''mipela kisim lo'').<ref name="r2004_47">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2004|p=47}}</ref>
What was likely the first government patrol of the Urapmin area was conducted in 1949 by Patrol Officer J. R. Rogers, accompanied by nine native policemen.<ref name="r2004_54">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2004|p=54}}</ref> Rogers convinced the Urapmin to make peace with the Tifalmin, stating that "fighting and cannibalism must cease."<ref name="r2004_54" /> The Urapmin performed a ''tisol dalamin'' ("equivalent exchange ceremony"), a traditional form of dispute resolution which had not been used before by the Urapmin to make peace with enemy peoples.<ref name="r2004_54" />
By the 60s the majority of the Telefomin region had been pacified.<ref name="c610">{{Harvcoltxt|Cranstone|1968|p=610}}</ref> Large numbers of Urapmin converted to Christianity between the mid-1960s and the mid-1970s.<ref name="r1998_301" /> The religion was brought to Urapmin by [[Telefol people|Telefol]] and Urapmin pastors who had studied in Telefomin at the Australian Baptist Mission.<ref name="r1998_301" /> While Urapmin never hosted expatriate missionaries, by the mid-1970s there were a number of knowledgeable Christians in the community.<ref name="r1998_301" /> However, the majority of conversions occurred during a [[Christian revival]] which swept the New Guinea Highlands in the late 1970s.<ref name="r2001_903" /> The ''rebaibal'', as it is known in [[Tok Pisin]], had begun in the [[Solomon Islands]] and reached Urapmin by 1977.<ref name="r1998_301" /> This movement caused all of the Urapmin to convert, and led to the rise of [[Charismatic Christianity]] among the Urapmin.<ref name="r1998_301" /><ref name="r2001_903" />
Urapmin society has been significantly affected by the [[Ok Tedi mine]].<ref name="r1998_300-301">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|1998|pp=300–301}}</ref> The mine is located in [[Tabubil]], built in the early 1980s, which is located two-and-a-half days by foot from Urapmin, or accessible by plane from Telefomin.<ref name="r1998_301">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|1998|p=301}}</ref> By the early 1990s, many Urapmin had begun visiting Tabubil once every few years, more frequently for prominent families.<ref name="r1998_301" /> For the Urapmin, Tabubil has become both a place where consumer goods are visible and a haven from sharing resources.<ref name="r1998_301" />
Few Urapmin have been employed by the mine at any time, and due to the lack of a road or airstrip, the Urapmin have been unable to market vegetables to the mine as have their neighbors.<ref name="r1995_213" /> As a result, the Urapmin have not experienced much of the economic development that has occurred to neighboring groups.<ref name="r1995_213" /> The Kennecott company began prospecting for gold on Urapmin land in 1989, raising hopes, and while the company left Papua New Guinea in 1992, the Urapmin remain optimistic about future prospecting.<ref name="r1995_213" />
== Geography == [[File:Papua new guinea west sepik province.png|thumb|300px|right|Location of the West Sepik Province of Papua New Guinea (dark red)]]
The Urapmin number about 375, living in the [[Telefomin District]] in [[West Sepik Province]], Papua New Guinea.<ref name="c609" /><ref name="r1998_300">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|1998|p=300}}</ref> Along with the more-numerous [[Telefol people]], they are located by the headwaters of the [[Sepik River]], the [[Telefomin valley]], and the nearby [[Elliptaman valley]].<ref name="b332-333">{{Harvcoltxt|Brumbaugh|1980|pp=332–333}}</ref> They live in a remote region; [[Telefomin]], the District Office, and an airstrip can only be reached by a difficult seventeen-mile walk.<ref name="r1998_300" />
The total area of Urapmin territory is small, and most villages are within walking distance.<ref name="rgeo2" /> Most of the Urapmin villages (Urap: ''abiip'') are located along the top of a ridge in the foothills of the [[Behrmann mountains]].<ref name="rgeo1">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2004|p=21}}</ref> The ridge is known in Urap as ''Bimbel'', named after the earthquake spirit ''Bim'' who is believed to have flattened out the ridge.<ref name="rgeo1" /><ref group="nb">The word for "earthquake" in Urap is also ''bim''. See {{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2004|p=21}}</ref> The villages along the Bimbel ridge are ''Danbel'' (''Muli Kona''), ''Salafaltigin'', ''Drum Tem'', ''Atemkit'', and ''Dimidubiip''.<ref name="rgeo1" />
There are also two villages known as "places at the sides" (Tok Pisin: ''saitsait ples'') which are near the ridge but not directly on top of it; these are ''Makalbel'' and ''Ayendubiip''.<ref name="rgeo1" /> Urapmin from the more northerly villages of Atemkit, Dimidubiip, and Ayendubiip are known as "bottom" Urapmin, while the others are known as "top" Urapmin.<ref name="rgeo2">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2004|p=22}}</ref>
== Culture == As with other remote Papuan groups, the central elements of Urapmin life are subsistence agriculture, hunting, and Christianity.<ref name="r1998_300" />
=== Language === {{main|Urapmin language|Tok Pisin}}
The native language of the Urapmin is known as the Urapmin or Urap language (Urap: ''urap weng''), a member of the [[Mountain Ok languages|Mountain Ok subfamily]] of the [[Ok languages]].<ref name="rlang1">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2004|p=37}}</ref> Although Urap is linguistically intermediate between its geographic neighbors [[Telefol language|Telefol]] and [[Tifal language|Tifal]], it is not a dialect of either.<ref name="rlang1" /><ref name="eth">{{cite web | title = Urapmin | publisher = [[SIL International]] | date = n.d. | url = http://www.ethnologue.org/show_language.asp?code=urm | accessdate = December 22, 2012}}</ref> Multilingualism among the Urapmin has led many Telefolmin to believe that the Urapmin speak Telefol among themselves, but this is not the case.<ref name="rlang1" /> Although the Urapmin view the [[Tifal language]] as being closer to Urap than the [[Telefol language]] is, and an early account claimed that the Urapmin speak Tifal, more recent research indicates that they should not be considered the same language.<ref name="rlang1" /> Urap remains in vigorous use among the Urapmin, and is the main language that they use.<ref name="rlang2">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2004|p=38}}</ref>
One unusual feature of the Urapmin language is the use of [[dyadic kinship term]]s.<ref name="rdyad1">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2004|p=300}}</ref> These terms translate into English as reciprocal kinship or affinity relations such as "(pair of) brothers" or "father and child", and may sometimes even refer to a relations between three or more people.<ref name="rdyad2">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2004|p=301}}</ref> These terms can encode relative age, kinship or affinity, number of members, and gender.<ref name="rdyad2" /> For example, a pair of siblings is ''alep'' (plural ''ningkil''), a pair of affines is ''kasamdim'' (plural ''amdimal''), a couple is ''agam'' (plural ''akmal''), a woman with a child is ''awat'' (plural ''aptil''), and a man with a child is ''alim'' (plural ''alimal'').<ref name="rdyad2" /><ref group="nb">Urapmin differs from [[Telefol language|Telefol]] in that it does not distinguish groups of siblings (''ningkil'') based on whether they are single or mixed sex groups. See {{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2004|p=348}}.</ref>
The plural forms are not marked for which generation is pluralized; thus ''alimal'' may either mean (a) one man and two children or (b) one man, one woman, and one child.<ref name="rdyad2" /> These terms are used to address groups, but not single individuals, so for example a mother of two children would never to referred to or addressed using the term ''aptil'' (rather, one would use ''alamon'' 'mother').<ref name="rdyad2" /> However, a pastor could address his congregation — a collection of husbands and their wives and children — as ''sios alimal'' 'church alimal' or just ''alimal''.<ref name="rdyad3">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2004|p=302}}</ref>
The [[Tok Pisin]] language is also widely used by the Urapmin.<ref name="rlang1" /> One of the national [[languages of Papua New Guinea]], Tok Pisin is an important [[lingua franca]] in rural areas.<ref name="rlang1" /> The Urapmin learn the language from older children and in school, becoming fluent around the age of twelve.<ref name="rlang1" /><ref group="nb">The language of schooling is nominally [[English language|English]], and use of Tok Pisin is officially forbidden. However, in effect students become literate in Tok Pisin, while never getting close to becoming fluent in English. See {{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2004|p=37}}.</ref> Tok Pisin is regularly used in daily life, and has contributed many loan words to Urap.<ref name="rlang2" /> In particular, Tok Pisin is associated with modernity and Western institutions and is regularly used in contexts such as local governance and Christian services and discussions.<ref name="rlang2" /> Unlike some other peoples in Papua New Guinea, the Urapmin have not attempted to find native equivalents for Tok Pisin terms related to Christianity.<ref name="rlang2" /> The New Testament edition most used by the Urapmin is in Tok Pisin, the ''Nupela Testamen Ol Sam'' published by the Bible Society of Papua New Guinea.<ref name="rlang3">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbin|2004|p=39}}</ref>
=== Economic system === [[File:Taro root CDC.jpg|thumb|right|A [[taro]] root, a [[staple food]] of the Urapmin]] The Urapmin practice [[slash-and-burn]] agriculture, and raise small numbers of pigs.<ref name="m306" /> The main source of sustenance for the Urapmin is [[taro]] (Urap: ''ima'') and [[sweet potato]] (Urap: ''wan''), grown in swidden gardens (Urap: ''lang'') in the bush.<ref name="r2004_24">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2004|p=24}}</ref> In fact the main word for "food" in Urap is formed by compounding these two nouns.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|1995|pp=212–213}}</ref> These are supplemented by [[banana]], [[pandanus]], [[sugar cane]], and various other [[cultigen]]s.<ref name="r1995_213">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|1995|pp=213}}</ref>
The hunting of marsupials, wild pigs, and other game is greatly valued in Urapmin culture, but it does not contribute significantly to sustenance.<ref name="m306" /> Domestic pigs are raised in only small numbers and killed on special occasions.<ref name="r1995_213" /> Tinned fish, rice, and frozen chicken must be brought in from Telefomin, the District Office, or Tabubil, and are considered by the Urapmin to be luxury goods.<ref name="r1995_213" />
As with many other Papuan groups, the Urapmin consider the owner of an object or land to be the first person to create or work it.<ref name="m307" /> This is taken to the extent that every object in a household is considered to have an owner, and some households have even divided their shared gardens into individually owned plots.<ref name="m307" /> According to the traditional beliefs of the Urapmin, this fits into a general worldview where everything had an owner, either human or spirit.<ref name="m307" />
=== Religion === The Urapmin stand out among "remote" [[hunter-gatherer]] societies in how strongly they have rejected their traditional beliefs and practices ([[Urap language|Urap]]: ''alowal imi kukup'', literally "ways of the ancestors") and embraced those of [[Protestant Christianity]].<ref name="r2001_903">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2001|p=903}}</ref> Unlike in other Papuan cultures, among the Urapmin there is no ongoing conflict between Christians (Tok Pisin: ''kristins'') and "heathens" (Tok Pisin: ''haidens'').<ref name="r1995_214">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|1995|p=214}}</ref> Some rituals are still subjects of debate among the Urapmin as to whether they should still be practiced, in particular pig sacrifice and bridewealth exchange.<ref name="r2001_904" />
====Traditional beliefs ==== According to traditional Urapmin belief all beings which existed in the world before the creation of humans were spirits.<ref name="afek" /> Humans were created in a multiple birth of the cultural heroine [[Afek (mythology)|Afek]], emerging immediately after the first dog (Urap: ''kyam'').<ref name="afek" /> Afek gave the bush to the spirits right before birthing humans so that they would clear out the villages for the humans to dwell in.<ref name="afek">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2006|pp=176–177}}</ref> Since as such dogs are spirits, and as the Urapmin say the "older brother" of man, the Urapmin do not kill or eat them, unlike some neighboring tribes, nor do they let dogs breathe on their food<ref name="afek" /> (this contrasts with humans – the Urapmin previously had no [[cannibalism]] taboo, and they may share food with them {{clarify |date=January 2017 |reason=unclear who "them" refers to. Probably the dogs, but with the interlude on cannibalism, it's weird. The lack of cannibalism taboo should probably be a new sentence}}).<ref name="afek" /> In fact, the taboo on eating dogs is one of the few still widely observed.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2006|pp=177, 190}}</ref>
Afek was viewed both as the physical mother of all [[Mountain Ok people|Min peoples]] other than the [[Baktaman]], and as the originator of all Min culture and religion.<ref name="mac32-33" /> The [[Telefol people|Telefol]], as the lastborn of Afek, were thus entrusted with the guardianship of her legacy<ref name="mac33" /> (the Urapmin were at or at least quite close to the level of the Telefol in this hierarchy of religious knowledge).<ref name="r2004_17">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2004|p=17}}</ref> The Min peoples believed Afek to have left her primary relics in the cult house in the village of [[Telefolip]] (a contraction of ''Telefol abiip'' 'village of the Telefol').<ref name="mac33" /> Afek was believed to have married a serpent who formed the glade that only men could enter to reach Telefolip upon its death throes.<ref name="c620">{{Harvcoltxt|Cranstone|1968|p=620}}</ref> Telefolip was never moved, and the buildings in Telefolip would constantly be rebuilt on the same locations.<ref name="mac33" />
The traditional law of the Urapmin was characterized by many rules about religious behavior and an elaborate taboo system, focused especially on eating and land use, as well as regulating what could be touched and who could know what information.<ref name="r1998_307">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|1998|p=307}}</ref><ref name="r1998_305" /> According to Urapmin tradition, Afek gave ownership of the wild (''sep'') to the ''motobil'' (nature spirits), who themselves gave ownership of the villages (''abiip'') to humans.<ref name="m307">{{Harvcoltxt|Moretti|2007|p=307}}</ref> Natural resources, including streams, large trees, hunting ground, and game were believed to be owned by the motobil, and humans could only use what they were given permission to respectfully.<ref name="m307" />
Violation of these rules was thought to cause illness.<ref name="m307" /> This system of taboos, known as ''awem'' in the Urapmin language, was well-developed and shaped everyday life.<ref name="r1998_305">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|1998|p=305}}</ref> Those who became ill due to disrespecting the land or animals of the motobil would pray for the spirits to "unhand" them, or if this did not work they would sacrifice pigs in order to appease the spirits.<ref name="m306">{{Harvcoltxt|Moretti|2007|p=306}}</ref><ref name="m307" /> Recently, the Urapmin required gold prospectors to sacrifice to these spirits before digging on their land, although this pre-emptive use of sacrifice is new to the Urapmin.<ref name="m306" />
''Awem'' was abandoned in the late 1970s once the community had transitioned to Christianity, which was understood to be opposed to the practice of taboo.<ref name="r1998_307-308">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|1998|pp=307–308}}</ref> The Urapmin refer to the current period as "free time" (Tok Pisin: ''fri taim''), a liberating era where food and ground are freely available.<ref name="r1998_307-308" /> However, while the Urapmin now believe that God rather than Afek created everything, they still believe in the existence of motobil, albeit as "bad spirits" (Urap: ''sinik mafak'').<ref name="r1995_214" /><ref name="m309">{{Harvcoltxt|Moretti|2007|p=309}}</ref>
They now believe that Afek and the other mythical Urapmin characters arose after the generations of "Adam and Eve, Cain and Abel, Noah and Abraham" and lied, claiming falsely that they had created everything and that breaking their taboos would induce illness.<ref name="r1995_216">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|1995|p=216}}</ref> Since the Urapmin now believe that God gave creation to humans to use, they see taking the motobils' property to be a moral imperative.<ref name="m309" /> However, the Urapmin still believe in motobil-induced illness, and therefore they do occasionally sacrifice to the motobil, despite this being against Christian teachings.<ref name="m309" />
The Urapmin still abide by a traditional ethical code which requires mutual support (Urapmin: ''dangdagalin'') and forbidden social actions (Urapmin: ''awem'', but distinct from the other form of ''awem''), including adultery, anger, fighting, and theft.<ref name="r1998_305" /> As in many other Melanesian societies, one who eats alone (Urapmin: ''feg inin'') is condemned, for a person should share his food with others (Urapmin: ''sigil'').<ref name="r1998_305" /> Ethical breaches could be fixed by rituals such as "buying the anger" (Urapmin: ''aget atul sanin''), "buying the shame" (''fitom sanin''), and these are still practiced today.<ref name="r1998_306,310">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|1998|pp=306, 310}}</ref> The Urapmin also used to ritually remove anger from the body in order to prevent disease, but this has now been replaced by prayer for God to remove one's anger.<ref name="r1998_306,310" />
The Urapmin used to practice a type of male [[initiation]] known in Urap as ''ban''.<ref name="r2001_904" /> These elaborate rituals, for which the [[Mountain Ok people|Min peoples]] are famous, were a central part of Urapmin social life.<ref name="b29">{{Harvcoltxt|Barker|2007|p=29}}</ref> The ''ban'' was a multistage process which involved beatings and manipulation of various objects.<ref name="r2001_904" /> At each stage, the initiate was offered revelations of secret knowledge (Urap: ''weng awem''), but at the next stage these would be shown to be false (Urap: ''famoul'').<ref name="r2001_904" /> These initiations have been abandoned with the adoption of Christianity, and the Urap have expressed relief at no longer having to administer the beatings which were involved.<ref name="r1998_307-308" />
==== Christianity ==== Due to the rise of Charismatic Christianity among the Urapmin, by the early 1990s, Urapmin Christianity was characterized by "healing, possession, constant prayer, confession, and frequent, lengthy church services."<ref name="r1998_301" /> As elsewhere in Papua New Guinea, the form of Christianity among the Urapmin focuses especially on "millennial themes"—the return of Jesus and impending judgement.<ref name="r1998_299">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|1998|p=299}}</ref> In particular, the central themes of Urapmin Christianity are the last days ([[Tok Pisin]]: ''las de''), meaning the imminent return of Jesus to take his followers to heaven, and the need to live an ethical Christian life (Tok Pisin: ''Kristin laip'') in order to be one of those taken in the last days.<ref name="r1998_301" />
Religious discourse often focuses on the need to control desires and obey the law of the Bible and the government in order to live a good Christian life.<ref name="r1998_301" /> These themes were traditionally important to the Urapmin even before the advent of Christianity.<ref name="r1998_301" /> Urapmin society recognizes an opposition between the character traits of willfulness ([[Urapmin language|Urapmin]]: ''futabemin'') and obeying the law (Urapmin: ''awem'') or the demands of others (Urapmin ''weng sankamin'', lit. "to hear speech").<ref name="r1998_303">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|1998|p=303}}</ref> Willfulness is defined as when one's will or desire (Urapmin: ''san'', Tok Pisin: ''laik'') causes one to ignore the demands of the law or other people.<ref name="r1998_303" />
Both traits are considered important; for example, a woman is expected to choose her husband by exercising her own will, rather than caving to the pressure of her family or her suitors.<ref name="r1998_304">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|1998|p=304}}</ref><ref group="nb">The practice of following the woman's desire in marriage is known in Tok Pisin as ''laik bilong meri''. Among many other Papuan groups, and in particular among the neighboring [[Telefol people|Telefomin]], ''laik bilong meri'' is a new practice associated with the colonial government. However, among Urapmin it is believed to be an old custom of theirs, as authenticated by the elaborate ritual surrounding it and in their oral genealogical records. See {{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|1998|p=314}}.</ref>
Many [[Melanesia]]n societies recognize such an opposition; however, while in other societies balance between willfulness and respecting others' needs is achieved by community leaders or by dividing these traits between men and women, in Urapmin society each individual must balance these him or herself.<ref name="r1998_302">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|1998|p=302}}</ref> However, the adoption of Christianity led to a vilification of willful behavior in general, since salvation could only be reached by following God's will; therefore, the focus of Urapmin culture became the suppression of desire.<ref name="r1998_307-308" />
The Urapmin have replaced traditional rituals with new, Christian methods for removing sin (Tok Pisin: ''sin'', Urapmin ''yum'', lit. debt).<ref name="r1998_307" /> The Urapmin have innovated an institution of [[confession (religion)|confession]] (Tok Pisin: ''autim sin''), which was not present in the [[Baptist Church]] which they belong to.<ref name="r1998_308">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|1998|p=308}}</ref><ref name="r2001_904" /> Confessions are held at least once a month, and some Urapmin keep lists of sins in order not to forget to confess them.<ref name="r1998_308" /> Pastors and other leaders regularly give haranguing lectures (Urapmin: ''weng kem'') about avoiding sin.<ref name="r1998_308" />
Another sin-removal ritual that the Urapmin practice is a form of group possession known as the "spirit disco" (Tok Pisin: ''spirit disko'').<ref name="r1998_310-311">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|1998|pp=310–311}}</ref> Men and women gather in church buildings, dancing in circles and jumping up and down while women sing Christian songs; this is called "pulling the [Holy] spirit" (Tok Pisin: ''pulim spirit'', Urap: ''Sinik dagamin'').<ref name="r1998_311">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|1998|p=311}}</ref><ref name="r2004_284">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2004|p=284}}</ref> The songs' melodies are borrowed from traditional women's songs sung at drum dances (Urap: ''wat dalamin''), and the lyrics are typically in Telefol or other [[Mountain Ok languages]].<ref name="r2004_284" /> If successful, some dancers will "get the spirit" (Tok Pisin: ''kisim spirit''), flailing wildly and careening about the dance floor.<ref name="r1998_311" />
After an hour or more, those possessed will collapse, the singing will end, and the spirit disco will end with a prayer and, if there is time, a Bible reading and sermon.<ref name="r1998_311" /> The body is believed to normally be "heavy" (Urap: ''ilum'') with sin, and possession is the process of the Holy Spirit throwing the sins from one's body, making the person "light" (Urap: ''fong'') again.<ref name="r1998_311" /> This is a completely new ritual for the Urapmin, who have no indigenous tradition of spirit-possession.<ref name="r1998_312">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|1998|p=312}}</ref>
The Urapmin practice frequent prayer (Tok Pisin: ''beten''), at least beginning and ending the day with prayer, and often praying a number of times throughout the day.<ref name="r2001_903" /> Prayer may be both communal and individual, for such things as health, agriculture, hunting, relief from anger, bad omens in dreams, blessing meals, removal of sin, and just to offer praise to God.<ref name="r2001_903" /> In addition to ritual speech during prayer, the Urapmin emphasize that a Christian life involves listening to "God's talk" (Urap: ''Gat ami weng'').<ref name="r2001_904" /> The centrality of speech in modern Urapmin Christianity contrasts sharply with the mainly ritual-based traditional Urapmin culture, where sacred speech might even be blatantly false.<ref name="r2001_904">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2001|p=904}}</ref> The Urapmin have a [[cliché]] that reflects this: "God is nothing but talk" (Urap: ''Gat ka weng katagup''; Tok Pisin: ''Gat em i tok tasol'').<ref name="r2001_904" />
=== Kinship ===
The Urapmin practice [[endogamy]].<ref name="r2004_24" /> Since the Urapmin community is quite small, numbering in the hundreds, and Urapmin do not marry first cousins, the result is that most Urapmin are related to each other relatively directly.<ref name="r2004_24" />
The Urapmin are divided into kinship classes known as ''tanum miit'' (literally "man origin").<ref name="rtanum">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2004|pp=191–192}}</ref> The five tanum miit currently in widespread use are the ''Awem Tem Kasel'', the ''Awalik'', the ''Atemkitmin'', the ''Amtanmin'', and the ''Kobrenmin''.<ref name="rtanum" /> There is also a ''Fetkiyakmin'' group which is dying out, and in the past there were other tanum miit which have already gone extinct.<ref name="rtanum" /> The tanum miit used to be related to specific ritual observances and secret mythologies.<ref name="rtanum" /> Supernatural powers were believed to be distributed among them; for example, one group controlled the wind and another the rain.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2004|p=52}}</ref> Currently, they are viewed as the largest landholding units, and each village is thought to have a dominant tanum miit.<ref name="rtanum" />
Tanum miit are inherited [[cognatic]]ly through both parents; so one person may be a member of four tanum miit at once just by considering his or her grandparents.<ref name="rtanum" /><ref group="nb">Tanum miit do not play a role in marriage, so a person may inherit less tanum miit from his or her grandparent if they share tanum miit. See {{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2004|pp=191–192}}.</ref> Because of the close family connections between all of the Urapmin, any Urapmin can assert membership in every tanum miit and some can calculate how they have inherited them.<ref name="rtanum" /> The ''tanum miit'' thus do little to differentiate people in Urapmin society, and their membership is "fluid".<ref name="r2004_24" /><ref name="rtanum" /> However, the kamokim ('big men'), the more influential Urapmin, may treat these groups as more exclusive in order to organize others' actions.<ref name="rtanum" />
=== Political system ===
The Urapmin have a group of leaders, known as ''kamokim'' (singular ''kamok'') in the Urapmin language and ''bikman'' in Tok Pisin.<ref name="b29" /> These leaders organize people into villages, help people pay bridewealth payments, speak at court cases, and organize work groups to carry out large-scale projects.<ref name="b29" /> The kamokim are held in high regard in all public spheres and are a common topic of conversation.<ref name="b29" />
The Urapmin make a division between the village (Urap: ''abiip'') and the bush (Urap: ''sep'').<ref name="r2006_176" /> These domains are kept separate, and the Urapmin keep their villages free of plant matter.<ref name="r2006_176">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2006|p=176}}</ref> Villages are U-shaped with dirt-packed plazas, with no grass or weeds.<ref name="r2004_23">{{Harvcoltxt|Robbins|2004|p=23}}</ref> Most Urapmin have at least one house in a village (Urap: ''am'').<ref name="r2004_24"/><ref name="r1998_304" /> However, due to the importance of forest gardens for sustenance, the Urapmin spend much of their time in isolated bush houses (Urap: ''sep am''), built in elaborate fashion near gardens and hunting grounds.<ref name="r2004_24" /><ref name="r1998_304" /> Villages are arranged by the kamokim, who coax people from ''sep am'' or from other villages.<ref name="r1998_304" /> When the kamok dies, the village inhabitants disperse.<ref name="r1998_304" />

'''World Sparrow Day''' is a day designated to raise awareness of the [[house sparrow]] and then other common birds to urban environments, and of threats to their populations, observed on 20 March.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-03-21/kanpur/31219946_1_sparrows-and-other-birds-world-sparrow-day-bird-lover|title='Save sparrows for nature's balance'|newspaper=Times of India|date=21 March 2012|publisher=Bennett, Coleman & Co.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/life-and-style/metroplus/article3024688.ece |newspaper=The Hindu|title=Spare a thought for the sparrow |last=Sathyendran |first=Nita |accessdate=22 March 2012|date=21 March 2012}}</ref> It is an international initiative by the [[Nature Forever Society]] of India in collaboration with the Eco-Sys Action Foundation (France) and numerous other national and international organisations across the world.<ref name=bnhs>{{cite web|url=http://www.bnhs.org/press/press-releases/252-chirp-for-the-sparrow-tweet-for-the-sparrow-on-world-sparrow-day.html|title='Chirp for the Sparrow, Tweet for the Sparrow' on World Sparrow Day|publisher=Bombay Natural History Society|date=7 July 2011|accessdate=8 May 2012}}</ref>
The Nature Forever Society was started by Mohammed Dilawar, an Indian conservationist who started his work helping the house sparrow in [[Nashik]], and who was named one of the "Heroes of the Environment" for 2008 by ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' for his efforts.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Time|title=Heroes of the Environment 2008: Mohammed Dilawar|first=Madhur|last=Singh|date=24 September 2008|url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,1841778_1841782_1841791,00.html|accessdate=8 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Mohammed Dilawar: World Sparrow Day March 20th |url=http://www.ecowalkthetalk.com/blog/2011/03/11/mohammed-dilawar-world-sparrow-day-march-20th/ |first=Bhavani |last=Prakash |work=Eco Walk the Talk |date=11 March 2011|accessdate=8 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Todd|first=Kim|year=2012|title=Sparrow|series=Animal|publisher=Reaktion Books|isbn=978-1-86189-875-3|page=150 }}</ref> The idea of marking World Sparrow Day came up during an informal discussion at the Nature Forever Society's office. The idea was to earmark a day for the house sparrow to convey the message of conservation of the house sparrow and other common birds and also mark a day of celebration to appreciate the beauty of the common biodiversity which is taken so much for granted. The first World Sparrow Day was celebrated in 2010 in different parts of the world. The day was celebrated by carrying out different various kinds of activities and events like art competitions, awareness campaigns, and sparrow processions as well as interactions with media.<ref name=bnhs/><ref name=background>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldsparrowday.org/background.html|work=World Sparrow Day|publisher=Nature Forever Society|title=Background|archivedate=8 May 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67WGPjYPr}}</ref>
World Sparrow Day also has a broader vision to provide a platform where people who are working on the conservation of the house sparrow and other common birds can network, collaborate and exchange conservation ideas which will lead to better science and improved results. It aims to provide a meeting ground for people from different parts of the world to come together and form a force that can play an important role in advocacy and in spreading the awareness on the need of conserving common biodiversity or species of lower conservation status.<ref name=bnhs/><ref name=background/>
==Sparrow Awards== To encourage efforts made towards this cause and to selflessly conserve the environment, NFS has instituted the first Sparrow Awards in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, on 20 March 2011. In 2013, one of the key facilitators who has joined forces with NFS and supports Sparrow Awards is ''Sustainuance'' magazine. The Editor-In-Chief of the magazine, Shashwat D.C. who convened the event and handed out the award to the winners stated, "These awardees are unsung heroes who come from all walks of life. And what is remarkable is that they usually work without any government funding and do not seek any recognition."
